column104: it undermines progress made by your preceding statement and makes an argument more likely. Try this response instead: Good choice. After you’ve expressed your agreement
column105: it’s time for you to share your perspective. The key to sharing persuasively is to present a story rather than an argument. In the words of Jonathan Haidt
column106: “The human mind is a story processor
column107: not a logic processor.” Stories are powerful because they capture attention
column110: elicit empathy and improve recall. As you converse with the Angry Uncle Bot
column111: you’ll notice a pattern. A handful of responses move the interaction forward while others make it halt or careen. Successful responses are part of a five-step process that makes conversations with the Angry Uncle Bot (and real angry uncles) less polarized and more productive. Ask Listen Reflect Agree Share Reflect Ask Listen Share Agree 1. Ask open-ended
column113: nonjudgmental questions. 2. Listen to what people you disagree with say and deepen your understanding with follow-up inquiries. 3. Reflect back their perspective by summarizing their answers and noting underlying emotions. 4. Agree before disagreeing by naming ways in which you agree with their point of view. 5. Share your perspective by telling a story about a personal experience. At the heart of the method is a simple idea: People cannot communicate effectively about politics when they feel threatened. Direct attacks – whether in the form of logical argument
column115: or name-calling – trigger the sympathetic nervous system
column118: and self-reflection. To have productive conversations
column119: we first need to make people feel safe. Most political conversations founder because challenges to our beliefs trigger our sympathetic nervous system. The goal is ensuring people feel safe enough during political dialogues to avoid this. That way the rational part of their brains stays in control and they’re better able to hear
column120: absorb and adapt to new information. While it’s a powerful approach
column121: it isn’t easy. It takes patience
column122: tolerance and conscious engagement to get through all five steps. The method puts the burden for keeping the conversation calm on you: Not only must you not trigger the other person
column123: but you must not get triggered yourself. Given the challenge
column124: it’s tempting to avoid political discussions in mixed company altogether. Why risk provoking your angry uncle when you can chat about pumpkin pie instead? The answer is that when we choose avoidance over engagement
column125: we are sacrificing a critical opportunity and responsibility to facilitate social and political change. Throughout American history
column126: important strides were made because people dared to share their political views with relatives. The civil rights movement
column130: the struggle for marriage equality – all gained acceptance through difficult conversations among family members who initially disagreed vehemently with one another. To improve political discourse
column131: remember your goal isn’t to score points
column132: vent or put people in their place; it’s to make a difference. And that means sharing your message in a way that people who disagree with you – including your angry uncle – can hear. Dr. Karin Tamerius is the founder and managing director of Smart Politics
column133: a nonprofit organization that teaches progressives how to communicate more effectively across partisan divides.  Produced by Stuart A. Thompson Advertisement

column1: ---split---2.0---split---https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/threat-pelosi-16-dems-back-leadership-59297501---split---Sixteen Democrats who've opposed Nancy Pelosi's quest to become speaker released a letter Monday saying they will vote for "new leadership" when the House picks its leaders in January
column2: underscoring a significant threat to her effort to lead her party's House majority in the next Congress. The letter's release suggests that rather than spending the next six weeks focusing on a fresh agenda to present to Americans
column3: House Democrats could be consumed with a bitter and attention-grabbing internal leadership fight. The battle pits the party's largely liberal and diverse membership backing Pelosi
column4: D-Calif.
column5: against a small group of mostly moderate male lawmakers. Of the 16 Democrats who signed the letter — which stops short of explicitly saying they will vote for an opposing candidate for speaker — all but two are men: Reps. Kathleen Rice of New York and California's Linda Sanchez. "We promised to change the status quo
column6: and we intend to deliver on that promise
column7: the authors wrote, referring to campaign pledges by a number of Democratic candidates. Therefore
column8: we are committed to voting for new leadership in both our Caucus meeting and on the House Floor." Pelosi has activated an aggressive campaign for the job involving House colleagues
column9: prominent outside Democrats and party-aligned interest groups. Her office distributed endorsements Monday from nine House Democrats who are military veterans and UnidosUS
column10: a Hispanic civil rights organization. Known as a precise vote counter with a keen sense of her caucus' leanings
column11: Pelosi is aided by the lack of a declared opponent and many weeks during which she can dangle choice committee assignments
column12: rules changes and other goodies to help attract support. "Leader Pelosi remains confident in her support among Members and Members-elect
column13: spokesman Drew Hammill said in a written statement. He said 94 percent of House Democrats declined to sign the letter, though Pelosi opponents said they expect others who didn't sign to vote against her. Though the mavericks' numbers represent a handful of the 232 House Democrats elected, plus five races still undecided, they could still garner enough opposition to thwart her. Pelosi seems certain to have enough support to become her party's nominee for speaker when House Democrats vote by secret ballot on Nov. 28. She will need only a majority of Democrats in that contest. But when the full House elects its new leaders Jan. 3, the speaker will need a majority 218 votes, assuming that no one votes present" or misses the vote and Republicans oppose her en masse
column14: as seems likely. At 232 seats
column15: Pelosi could afford to lose just 14 Democrats and still become speaker. The rebels' letter to their Democratic colleagues praises Pelosi
column17: as "a historic figure" who helped win major victories. Pelosi was speaker from 2007 through 2010 when Democrats held the majority and has been the party's leader since 2003. "We also recognize that in this recent election
column18: Democrats ran and won on a message of change
column19: they wrote. Our majority came on the backs of candidates who said that they would support new leadership because voters in hard-won districts
column20: and across the country
column21: want to see real change in Washington." Pelosi's critics say the party's long-serving top leaders must make room for younger members. They say years of Republican ads portraying her as an out-of-touch liberal have made it hard for moderate Democrats to win in swing districts. Pelosi allies counter that the party just won House control with their biggest gain of seats since the 1974 post-Watergate election. Many bristle at dumping her at a time when President Donald Trump and the #MeToo movement have helped attract female candidates and voters to the party. Rep. Steny Hoyer of Maryland has been No. 2 House Democrat since 2003 and South Carolina's Jim Clyburn has been No. 3 since 2007. Both are in their late 70s and are running
column22: unopposed so far
column23: for those posts again. Of the letter's signees
column24: five are incoming House freshmen or hope to be. Two of them — Anthony Brindisi of New York and Ben McAdams of Utah — are in races in which The Associated Press has yet to call a winner. Pelosi critics assert there are more Democrats who've not signed the letter who are prepared to vote against Pelosi. That includes Rep. Marcia Fudge of Ohio
column25: who's said she's considering running for speaker. Trump has tweeted his respect for Pelosi and offered to round up GOP votes to help elect her speaker. Pelosi's office has said she will win with Democratic votes
column26: and it seems a stretch to expect Republicans to help elect her speaker — a vote that could open them up to primary challenges in 2020. Others signing were incumbents Jim Cooper of Tennessee; Bill Foster of Illinois; Brian Higgins of New York; Stephen Lynch and Seth Moulton of Massachusetts; Ed Perlmutter of Colorado; Tim Ryan of Ohio; Kurt Schrader of Oregon and Filemon Vela of Texas. Incoming freshmen were Joe Cunningham of South Carolina
column27: Max Rose from New York and Jeff Van Drew of New Jersey.

column1: ---split---2.0---split---https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/saudi-kings-speech-makes-mention-slain-journalist-59289309---split---Saudi Arabia's King Salman on Monday gave his first major speech since the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents
column2: expressing support for his son
column3: the crown prince
column4: and making no mention of allegations that the young royal ordered the killing. The annual policy speech by the king instead highlighted Saudi Arabia's priorities for the coming year
column5: focusing on issues such as the war in Yemen
column6: security for Palestinians
column7: stability in the oil market
column8: countering rival Iran and job creation for Saudis. The king voiced support for his favored son
column9: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman
column10: saying that the 32-year-old heir to the throne is focused on developing the capabilities of Saudi youth. The prince oversees all major levers of power in the kingdom
column11: ranging from security to the economy. "The country is working tirelessly to create more jobs and training for Saudi youth
column12: Salman said. The crown prince
column13: chairman of the Council of Economic Affairs and Development
column14: has focused on developing human capabilities and preparing the new generation for future jobs." Saudi media reported Monday that the crown prince will attend the Group of 20 summit in Buenos Aires later this month. It would be the first trip abroad for the crown prince after the Oct. 2 slaying of Khashoggi
column15: and would bring him face to face with world leaders from the U.S.
column16: Turkey
column17: Canada and European countries that have strongly criticized the kingdom for the brutal killing. King Salman delivered his remarks in the ornate hall of the consultative Shura Council before the country's ministers
column18: senior officials
column19: military officers and clerics. Prince Mohammed was in attendance and seated next to the country's top cleric. In the wake of Khashoggi's killing inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul
column20: the 82-year-old monarch put Prince Mohammed in charge of overseeing the reorganization of intelligence services. The king's speech made no reference to that
column21: but he did commend Saudi Arabia's judiciary and public prosecution for their work in seeking justice in accordance with Islamic law. He said the kingdom "takes pride in the blessed efforts" of the judiciary and public prosecution
column22: adding that Saudi Arabia affirms its commitment to the application of Islamic law. On Thursday
column23: Saudi prosecutors said they are seeking the death penalty against five men suspected of killing Khashoggi
column24: who had written critically of the crown prince in columns for The Washington Post. The prosecutor's announcement sought to quiet the global outcry over Khashoggi's death and distance the killers and their operation from the crown prince. U.S. intelligence officials
column25: however
column26: have concluded that the crown prince ordered the killing
column27: according to a U.S. official familiar with the assessment. Others familiar with the case caution that while it's likely that the crown prince was involved in the death
column28: there continue to be questions about what role he played. Saudi investigators say a high-ranking adviser to the crown prince
column29: Saud al-Qahtani
column30: and a senior intelligence official
column31: Ahmed al-Assiri
column32: concocted a plan to force Khashoggi to return to Saudi Arabia
column33: deeming his presence abroad as a threat to national security. Saudi prosecutors say the 15-man team sent to Istanbul exceeded their authority when the lead negotiator in the team decided to kill Khashoggi for refusing orders to return. The Saudis say the agents killed Khashoggi with tranquilizers and then dismembered his body
column34: which has not been found. Those findings came after Saudi authorities spent weeks denying Khashoggi had been killed in the embassy. This past week
column35: U.S. intelligence officials briefed members of the Senate and House intelligence committees on their conclusions
column36: and the Treasury Department announced economic sanctions on 17 Saudi officials suspected of being responsible for or complicit in the killing. Among those sanctioned was al-Qahtani
column37: who was fired from his post as the crown prince's adviser after details of the killing emerged. President Donald Trump has said his administration will get "a very full report
column38:
including who was responsible for Khashoggi's death, on Monday or Tuesday. Trump has criticized the Saudi response to the killing, but has been reluctant to say definitively if he thinks the crown prince ordered it. ——— Batrawy reported from Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Associated Press writer Malak Harb contributed to this report from Dubai.
---split---2.0---split---https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/tijuana-residents-protest-migrant-caravan-camped-city-59279696---split---Hundreds of Tijuana residents congregated around a monument in an affluent section of the city south of California on Sunday to protest the thousands of Central American migrants who have arrived via caravan in hopes of a new life in the U.S. Tensions have built as nearly 3,000 migrants from the caravan poured into Tijuana in recent days after more than a month on the road, and with many more months ahead of them while they seek asylum. The federal government estimates the number of migrants could soon swell to 10,000. U.S. border inspectors are processing only about 100 asylum claims a day at Tijuana's main crossing to San Diego. Asylum seekers register their names in a tattered notebook managed by migrants themselves that had more than 3,000 names even before the caravan arrived. On Sunday, displeased Tijuana residents waved Mexican flags, sang the Mexican national anthem and chanted Out! Out!" in front of a statue of the Aztec ruler Cuauhtemoc
column39: 1 mile (1.6 kilometers) from the U.S. border. They accused the migrants of being messy
column40: ungrateful and a danger to Tijuana. They also complained about how the caravan forced its way into Mexico
column41: calling it an "invasion." And they voiced worries that their taxes might be spent to care for the group. "We don't want them in Tijuana
column42: protesters shouted. Juana Rodriguez, a housewife, said the government needs to conduct background checks on the migrants to make sure they don't have criminal records. A woman who gave her name as Paloma lambasted the migrants, who she said came to Mexico in search of handouts. Let their government take care of them
column43: she told video reporters covering the protest. A block away, fewer than a dozen Tijuana residents stood with signs of support for the migrants. Keyla Zamarron, a 38-year-old teacher, said the protesters don't represent her way of thinking as she held a sign saying: Childhood has no borders. Most of the migrants who have reached Tijuana via caravan in recent days set out more than a month ago from Honduras, a country of 9 million people. Dozens of migrants in the caravan who have been interviewed by Associated Press reporters have said they left their country after death threats. But the journey has been hard, and many have turned around. Alden Rivera, the Honduran ambassador in Mexico, told the AP on Saturday that 1,800 Hondurans have returned to their country since the caravan first set out on Oct. 13, and that he hopes more will make that decision. We want them to return to Honduras
column44: said Rivera. Honduras has a murder rate of 43 per 100,000 residents, similar to U.S. cities like New Orleans and Detroit. In addition to violence, migrants in the caravan have mentioned poor economic prospects as a motivator for their departures. Per capita income hovers around $120 a month in Honduras, where the World Bank says two out of three people live in poverty. The migrants' expected long stay in Tijuana has raised concerns about the ability of the border city of more than 1.6 million people to handle the influx. While many in Tijuana are sympathetic to the migrants' plight and trying to assist, some locals have shouted insults, hurled rocks and even thrown punches at them. The cold reception contrasts sharply with the warmth that accompanied the migrants in southern Mexico, where residents of small towns greeted them with hot food, campsites and even live music. Tijuana Mayor Juan Manuel Gastelum has called the migrants' arrival an avalanche" that the city is ill-prepared to handle
column45: calculating that they will be in Tijuana for at least six months as they wait to file asylum claims. Gastelum has appealed to the federal government for more assistance to cope with the influx. Mexico's Interior Ministry said Saturday that the federal government was flying in food and blankets for the migrants in Tijuana. Tijuana officials converted a municipal gymnasium and recreational complex into a shelter to keep migrants out of public spaces. The city's privately run shelters have a maximum capacity of 700. The municipal complex can hold up to 3
column46: 000. At the municipal shelter
column47: Josue Caseres
column49: expressed dismay at the protests against the caravan. "We are fleeing violence
column50: said the entertainer from Santa Barbara, Honduras. How can they think we are going to come here to be violent?" Some from the caravan have diverted to other border cities
column51: such as Mexicali
column52: a few hours to the east of Tijuana. Elsewhere on Sunday
column53: a group of 200 migrants headed north from El Salvador
column54: determined to also find safety in numbers to reach the U.S. Edwin Alexander Gomez
column56: told AP in San Salvador that he wants to work construction in New York
column57: where he hears the wages are better and the city is safer. U.S. President Donald Trump
column58: who sought to make the caravan a campaign issue in the midterm elections
column59: used Twitter on Sunday to voice support for the mayor of Tijuana and try to discourage the migrants from seeking entry to the U.S. Trump wrote that like Tijuana
column60: "the U.S. is ill-prepared for this invasion
column61: and will not stand for it. They are causing crime and big problems in Mexico. Go home!" He followed that tweet by writing: "Catch and Release is an obsolete term. It is now Catch and Detain. Illegal Immigrants trying to come into the U.S.A.
column62: often proudly flying the flag of their nation as they ask for U.S. Asylum
column63: will be detained or turned away." ——— Guthrie reported from Mexico City. Associated Press writer Julie Watson contributed to this story from Tijuana and Marcos Aleman contributed from San Salvador.

column9: we’ve rounded up all the news we didn’t break or cover in depth this week. Click on the headlines to read the full stories. And stay safe out there. The most cybersecure devices are the ones that aren’t connected to the internet at all. Japan’s minister of cybersecurity Yoshitaka Sakurada appears to have taken that advice a little far
column10: admitting in front of Japanese parliament this week that he has actually never used a computer. At all. The nation of Japan was understandably aghast. When asked whether nuclear power plants in the country allowed USB drives to be used on their computers
column11: Sakurada admitted he didn’t know what a USB drive was. He told parliament if they need to have better answers they should bring in an expert. Though the story is funny in a “this is fine” meme kind of way
column12: it’s actually terrifying
column13: and exemplifies a growing trend of nonexperts in governing positions—and not just in Japan. American lawmakers are increasingly without expertise in the areas they’re assigned to oversee. After the midterms
column14: it made headlines that a lawmaker with an actual science background would be leading the House science committee. It was news because it was such a rarity. This isn’t really fine
column15: is it? It happened in 2016. And now it’s happened again. A judge in New Hampshire has said that Amazon’s Alexa may have heard the stabbing murder of two women. The judge ruled this week that Amazon should hand over the records to prosecutors in the case against the man accused. Amazon said it will only deliver the recordings with a binding legal order
column16: which it appeared to deny the ruling constituted. In an apparent error

column18: or even the charge itself
column19: are meant to be known by the public. The unrelated filing stated: “Due to the sophistication of the defendant and the publicity surrounding the case
column20: no other procedure is likely to keep confidential the fact that Assange has been charged.” It went on to indicate the US plans to arrest Assange
column21: who is reportedly wearing out his welcome at the Ecuadorian Embassy in London
column22: where he’s been hiding for the past six years. A spokesman for the court told The Washington Post

column24: which has been investigating the role Wikileaks played in Russia’s misinformation attack on the US presidential election in 2016. Facebook says that US government requests for user data have gone up by 30 percent year over year. Most of these were court-ordered search warrants
column25: which the company prevented from alerting users about. The figures were released in its latest transparency report
column26: which came out a day after The New York Times bombshell investigation into the company’s mishandling of Russian misinformation on the platform during the presidential election. Facebook’s transparency report also reveals that between 2014 and 2017
column27: Facebook reports the US government served it with 13 national security letters
column28: the secret subpoenas the FBI issues to companies for data without any judicial oversight
column29: and about which companies are often prevented from discussing publicly. Facebook disclosed the information after the government lifted the gag orders on these specific NSLs earlier this year
column30: according to Facebook’s deputy general counsel Chris Sonderby. As if its traffic being rerouted erroneously through Russia and China wasn’t bad enough

column32: the account promoted a bitcoin scam to its more than 800
column33: 000 followers. The Next Web reports the hack was part of a string Bitcoin related scams going around. Earlier that same day Target’s Twitter account had done the same thing. In good news
column34: internet security company Cloudflare released a mobile version of its 1.1.1.1 public DNS resolver
column35: which works to protect your browsing privacy while on a public internet connection by hiding your IP address. Available for iOS and Android devices
column36: the app is free and early reviews suggest it’s fast. It seems like every time you turn around there's a new breach of personal information. Follow these steps to minimize the damage. column6: Texas – Marianna Trevino-Wright
column7: executive director of the National Butterfly Center
column8: is preparing for the inevitable. The 100-acre nature preserve on the U.S.-Mexico border sits in the path of a border wall that will soon be built. In more than three months
column9: government contractors will begin work on the levee road that divides the property. “They will be clearing all the trees and vegetation from this area to create their enforcement zone. They’re going to excavate the earth and levee
column10: put in an 18-foot vertical concrete slab wall
column11: and on top of that 18-foot steel bollards
column12: ” said Trevino-Wright. In the last two weeks
column13: U.S. Customs and Border Protection
column14: in partnership with the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
column15: announced the construction of two additional border walls in Hidalgo County in southern Texas. One wall would stretch six miles and cut through the preserve
column16: and the other would span eight miles. Both contracts were awarded to Galveston-based SLSCO Ltd. The two projects
column17: totaling $312 million
column18: would begin in February. The National Butterfly Center in Mission is just one of several places that would be affected by the new border wall. (Fox News) The government in the beginning stages of building the border wall
column19: recently started issuing right of entry requests
column20: giving them the right to explore the land to figure out where to best put up the wall. That has set up a potential battle between the government and longtime landowners in the area where the wall will go up. “For some of (the landowners)
column21: the land has been there for generations. It’s very meaningful to them
column22: ” said Efren Olivares
column23: legal director for Racial and Economic Justice at the Texas Civil Rights Project
column24: who has been working with several other landowners in the Valley
column25: advising them on their rights and the government’s right of entry requests. “That’s why they don’t want it destroyed by building a wall through it.” Some believe the wall would degrade their property. “We’re going to lose 70 percent of our land to the border wall because the border wall is not on the border
column26: ” said Trevino-Wright
column27: who has been fighting the project since July 2017. “In some places
column28: the habitat would be bulldozed entirely.” The expected construction site in the National Butterfly Center is located about one mile north of the Rio Grande River
column29: which divides the United States and Mexico. In October
column30: the Trump administration waived 28 environmental and public-health laws to make way for the construction of 18 miles of border wall. While some local landowners here are against the wall
column31: others are in favor of it
column32: arguing they are fed up with migrants illegally entering the country through their land. The new wall would run along this levee road of the National Butterfly Center
column33: separating 70 acres on the southern section of the levee. (Fox News) Othal Brand
column34: president of Hidalgo County Water Improvement District 3
column35: also received a right of entry request – but he was happy about it. “Some people say ‘oh
column36: you want a wall?’ I believe in securing the border
column37: ” Brand said. “For those that live in a city

column39: it is a totally different environment.” Brand
column40: who has lived and worked along the river for generations
column41: already has a border wall running through his land. He said he noticed a drop in illegal activity after it was built. Conservation groups have filed a lawsuit against the Trump administration for the move
column42: saying it will destroy the area’s wildlife and natural habitat. But
column43: security experts believe there’s a reason why the locations were chosen. “I do understand the unfortunate nature of some of these locations. On the flip side
column44: though
column45: you’re having these walls constructed in areas where you have heavy smuggling operations in both directions
column46: which I think is an important aspect to remember here
column47: ” said Fred Burton
column48: chief security officer at Stratfor. U.S. Customs and Border Protection have called the Rio Grande Valley Sector the busiest in the country for illegal activity. column2: leading the network to drop its pending lawsuit against the administration. “Having received a formal reply from your counsel to our letter of November 16
column3: we have made a final determination in this process: your hard pass is restored
column4: ” the White House wrote in a letter to Acosta
column5: according to CNN. “Should you refuse to follow these rules in the future
column6: we will take action in accordance with the rules set forth above. The President is aware of this decision and concurs.” The letter also included a revised code of conduct for journalists during presidential press conferences. Per White House letter to Acosta on Nov. 19
column7: here are the new rules for press conferences at the White House. pic.twitter.com/a6C2pmLv2K The White House initially revoked Acosta’s press pass after a press conference on Nov. 7
column8: during which the reporter and President Donald Trump had a heated exchange. A White House intern grabbed the microphone from the Acosta
column9: and the White House later shared a sped-up video of the event that suggested the reporter used force against the intern. CNN sued the Trump administration for violating the First Amendment rights of both the network and its reporter. We stand by our decision to revoke this individual’s hard pass. We will not tolerate the inappropriate behavior clearly documented in this video. pic.twitter.com/T8X1Ng912y Acosta’s pass was restored Friday after Judge Timothy J. Kelly ruled that Acosta’s right to due process had been violated. However
column10: the White House indicated Friday in a letter that Acosta’s press pass could be revoked again as soon as the temporary restraining order granted by Kelly expired. The letter
column11: signed by White House press secretary Sarah Huckabee Sanders and deputy chief of staff for communications Bill Shine
column12: claims Acosta “failed to abide” by “basic
column13: widely understood practices.” Earlier on Monday
column14: CNN sought an emergency court hearing in response to that letter. The filing was aimed at protecting Acosta’s access until the network’s initial lawsuit against the administration was decided. CNN’s communications department tweeted Monday afternoon that the network’s “lawsuit is no longer necessary” and that CNN looks “forward to continuing to cover the White House.” Acosta also tweeted on Monday afternoon
column15: saying: “Thanks to everybody for their support. As I said last Friday... let’s get back to work.” Do you have information you want to share with HuffPost? Here’s how.

column1: ---split---2.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/trump-head-mississippi-amid-gop-concerns-senate-seat---split---Mississippi Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith faces Democrat Mike Espy in a Nov. 27 runoff. (Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call file photo) President Donald Trump will make an eleventh-hour attempt to keep a Mississippi Senate seat in Republican hands later this month when he headlines two rallies there the day before a runoff election. His campaign organization announced Saturday the president will hold two rallies on Nov. 26 on behalf of Republican Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith. He will be in Tupelo at 5 p.m. and then in Biloxi three hours later. Hyde-Smith faces former Democratic Rep. Mike Espy in the special election runoff after neither cleared 50 percent in the Nov. 6 jungle primary
column2: which saw two Republicans and two Democrats run together on the same ballot. Hyde-Smith was appointed to the seat in April after GOP Sen. Thad Cochran resigned over health reasons. The special election winner gets to serve out the final two years of Cochran’s term. Hyde-Smith earned national headlines in recent days after the release of video showing her making controversial remarks. In one
column3: she’s heard saying she’d be “on the front row” if invited by a supporter to a public hanging. In another
column4: she indicated support for making it “just a little more difficult” for liberal college students to vote. Her campaign has called the first remarks “an exaggerated expression of regard” for the supporter and said the latter comments were made in jest. The Mississippi Senate runoff gives Trump another chance to get back on the campaign trail after his frustrations with the media’s coverage of the midterms
column5: which saw Republicans lose control of the House while picking up likely two seats to expand their narrow Senate majority. The president has painted the midterms as a success
column6: pointing to the Senate gains
column7: while arguing that previous presidents lost more House seats. He has also bragged about campaigning for 10 GOP candidates
column8: saying he helped nine of them win. Inside Elections with Nathan L. Gonzales rates the Mississippi special Senate election Solid Republican. column1: ---split---2.0---split---http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/public-hanging-mississippi-senate-runoff---split---Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith
column2: R-Miss.
column3: has provoked widespread outrage for joking about "public hanging" at a campaign event in a newly surfaced video. (Photo By Bill Clark/CQ Roll Call) At a campaign event earlier this month
column4: Mississippi Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith and her supporters laughed as she quipped about being in the front row of a “public hanging
column5: ” according to a newly surfaced video. “If he invited me to a public hanging
column6: I’d be on the front row
column7: ” the Republican said in an embrace with one of her supporters
column8: according to a video posted by an independent journalist to Twitter and Facebook on Sunday. Outraged observers say the Hyde-Smith’s comment evokes the bloody history of lynchings in Mississippi
column9: which has the deadliest record of racist mob violence by hanging of any state in the United States
column10: according to the NAACP. The video has also drawn new attention to her runoff race against Democratic challenger and former U.S. agriculture secretary Mike Espy
column11: who is black. Hyde-Smith and Espy were the top performers on Election Day
column12: but neither candidate garnered 50 percent of the vote
column13: triggering a runoff. Mississippi voters will go to the polls again on Nov. 27. Gov. Phil Bryant appointed Hyde-Smith to fill Sen. Thad Cochran’s seat when he retired due to his health in March. "If he invited me to a public hanging
column14: I'd be on the front row"- Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith says in Tupelo

column17: praises her.  Hyde-Smith referred to the remark as “an exaggerated expression of regard” in a statement. “In a comment on Nov. 2
column18: I referred to accepting an invitation to a speaking engagement
column19: ” said. “In referencing the one who invited me
column20: I used an exaggerated expression of regard
column21: and any attempt to turn this into a negative connotation is ridiculous.” In its own statement
column22: the Espy campaign called her comments “reprehensible.” “They have no place in our political discourse
column23: in Mississippi
column24: or our country
column25: ” said Campaign Communications Director Danny Blanton. “We need leaders
column26: not dividers
column27: and her words show that she lacks the understanding and judgement to represent the people of our state.” The midterm election has stirred a debate about the role of race in U.S. politics as Democrats and other observers have accused Republicans across the country of appealing to racial animus. NAACP President Derrick Johnson drew a parallel from Hyde-Smith’s remarks to President Donald Trump. They “prove once again how Trump has created a social and political climate that normalizes hateful and racist rhetoric
column28: ” he said in a statement. “Hyde-Smith’s decision to joke about ‘hanging
column29: ’ in a state known for its violent and terroristic history toward African Americans is sick
column30: ” he said. “To envision this brutal and degenerate type of frame during a time when Black people
column31: Jewish People and immigrants are still being targeted for violence by White nationalists and racists is hateful and hurtful. Any politician seeking to serve as the national voice of the people of Mississippi should know better. Her choice of words serves as an indictment of not only her lack of judgement
column32: but her lack of empathy
column33: and most of all lack of character.” Hyde-Smith's voting record closely aligns with the White House’s policy agenda; the senator has campaigned on building a wall at the southern border with Mexico and supported the president’s ban on travel from several Muslim-majority countries. Hyde-Smith and Espy will participate in a debate on Nov. 20. column9: 2018. Protesters accused the migrants of being messy

(AP Photo/Rodrigo Abd) The border fence that divides Mexico with the United States is seen in Tecate, Mexico, Sunday, Nov. 18, 2018. (AP Photo/Rodrigo Abd) TIJUANA, Mexico – The United States closed off northbound traffic for several hours at the busiest border crossing with Mexico to install new security barriers on Monday, a day after hundreds of Tijuana residents protested against the presence of thousands of Central American migrants. The U.S. also closed one of two pedestrian crossings at the San Ysidro crossing in a move apparently aimed at preventing any mass rush of migrants across the border. The installation of movable, wire-topped barriers threatens to complicate life for Mexicans using San Ysidro, where about 110,000 people enter the U.S. every day in 40,000 vehicles. Long lines backed up in Tijuana, where many people have to cross the border to work on the U.S. side. Such inconveniences prompted by the arrival of the migrant caravan may have played a role in Sunday's protests, when about 400 Tijuana residents waved Mexican flags, sang the Mexican national anthem and chanted Out! Out!" referring to the migrant caravan that arrived in the border city last week. Tensions have built as nearly 3
column13: 000 migrants from the caravan poured into Tijuana in recent days after more than a month on the road — and with many more months likely ahead of them while they seek asylum in the U.S. The federal government estimates the number of migrants could soon swell to 10
column14: 000. U.S. border inspectors are processing only about 100 asylum claims a day at Tijuana's main crossing to San Diego. Asylum seekers register their names in a tattered notebook managed by migrants themselves that had more than 3
column15: 000 names even before the caravan arrived. Some Tijuana residents supported the migrants
column16: but others accused the migrants of being messy
column17: ungrateful and a danger to Tijuana. They also complained about how the caravan forced its way into Mexico
column18: calling it an "invasion." And they voiced worries that their taxes might be spent to care for the group. "We don't want them in Tijuana
column19: protesters shouted. Juana Rodriguez, a housewife, said the government needs to conduct background checks on the migrants to make sure they don't have criminal records. A block away, fewer than a dozen Tijuana residents stood with signs of support for the migrants. Keyla Zamarron, a 38-year-old teacher, said the protesters don't represent her way of thinking as she held a sign saying: Childhood has no borders." Most of the migrants who have reached Tijuana via caravan in recent days set out more than a month ago from Honduras
column20: a country of 9 million people. Dozens of migrants in the caravan who have been interviewed by Associated Press reporters have said they left their country after death threats. But the journey has been hard
column21: and many have turned around. Alden Rivera
column22: the Honduran ambassador in Mexico
column23: told the AP on Saturday that 1
column24: 800 Hondurans have returned to their country since the caravan first set out on Oct. 13
column25: and that he hopes more will make that decision. "We want them to return to Honduras
column26: said Rivera. The migrants' expected long stay in Tijuana has raised concerns about the ability of the border city of more than 1.6 million people to handle the influx. Tijuana Mayor Juan Manuel Gastelum has called the migrants' arrival an avalanche" that the city is ill-prepared to handle
column27: calculating that they will be in Tijuana for at least six months as they wait to file asylum claims. Gastelum has appealed to the federal government for more assistance to cope with the influx. Tijuana officials converted a municipal gymnasium and recreational complex into a shelter to keep migrants out of public spaces. The city's privately run shelters have a maximum capacity of 700. The municipal complex can hold up to 3
column28: 000. At the municipal shelter

(Chris Maddaloni/CQ Roll Call file photo) A Federal Housing Finance Agency manager leveled charges of unwanted advances and sexual harassment against Director Melvin Watt during a hearing Thursday before the House Financial Services Committee. Simone Grimes testified that beginning in 2015
column2: when she brought to the regulator’s attention that she was to be paid less than her predecessor in an executive position
column3: Watt offered her a “number of positions” but made clear each time that he had “an attraction” to her. “Director Watt made multiple unwanted advances toward me
column4: ” she told the committee. “The frequency of these advances . . . led me to begin recording many of our interactions
column5: ” said Grimes
column6: who has brought an Equal Pay action in federal court against the agency and Watt. She also has accused the FHFA Office of Inspector General in its investigation of her allegations to have exhibited a “lack of independence.” Grimes testified that she recorded 15 conversations with Watt that she believes a listener would conclude amounted to harassment. She said she turned all the recordings over to the committee and that the inspector general's office has sued her to obtain copies. Chairman Jeb Hensarling
column7: R-Texas
column8: emphasizing that the committee “is not a court of law
column9: ” cast the allegations against Watt and other investigations
column10: including the committee’s investigation
column11: as indicators of problems at the regulator and the entities it regulates. “Housing finance is in dire need of reform and FHFA is in dire need of oversight
column12: ” Hensarling said. He noted that a simultaneous hearing a the Senate Judiciary Committee concerning accusations of sexual assault against Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh might overshadow his panel’s hearing. “I’m not sure this hearing will be heard
column13: but it should
column14: ” he said. Watt is scheduled to testify later Thursday
column15: as is Laura Wertheimer
column16: the FHFA’s inspector general who has investigated the allegations. Testimony filed by Wertheimer and Watt did not make reference to Grimes' allegations. “Since these allegations were raised
column17: the Agency and the Director have had separate legal counsel on this matter
column18: ” the FHFA said in a statement Thursday. The agency said there are currently three investigations into the allegations
column19: by the FHFA inspector general
column20: the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission and by the U.S. Postal Service on behalf of FHFA. There is also a federal lawsuit that FHFA is a party to based on the Equal Pay Act
column21: the agency said. “[Watt] has not made any decisions on behalf of the Agency with respect to any of these legal reviews
column22: ” the statement said. “Further
column23: the Director has had no involvement of any kind in any employment decisions relating to the complainant since these allegations were raised." Ranking member Maxine Waters
column24: D-Calif.
column25: who had urged Hensarling to allow Grimes’ testimony
column26: said that she has long been a friend of former Rep. Watt
column27: who served on the Financial Services committee when he was a Democratic member from North Carolina. “If this were a jury in a court of law

column30: who has raised deeply troubling allegations against [Watt] . . . is heard before this committee.” Republicans on the committee have been critical of FHFA’s 10-year oversight of housing finance giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
column31: since the pair were taken into federal conservatorship at the onset of the financial crisis in 2008. Both parties have said they were in favor of overhauling the finance system

(Tom Williams/CQ Roll Call file photo) Democrat Jared Golden has defeated Maine Rep. Bruce Poliquin in the nation’s first use of ranked-choice voting for a congressional race
column2: according to state election officials. The Democrat won just over 50 percent of the vote in the ranked-choice tabulation
column3: meaning he’ll be the next congressman from the 2nd District unless Poliquin’s legal challenges to the voting system prevail. A Golden win in the 2nd District
column4: which President Donald Trump carried in 2016
column5: mean Democrats have picked up 35 seats and wiped out all New England Republicans in the House. Poliquin led Golden by less than a point on the first count
column6: but since neither candidate received 50 percent of the vote
column7: the state’s ranked-choice voting system kicked in to determine the winner. The new system
column8: which voters have twice approved at the ballot box
column9: lets voters rank candidates in order of preference. If no one receives a majority
column10: the last-place finisher is eliminated and his or her votes reallocated to the candidates whom voters ranked second. The process continues until someone secures more than 50 percent of the vote. A federal judge on Thursday morning rejected a lawsuit from Poliquin that sought to stop the secretary of state from running the ranked-choice voting tabulation. But Poliquin’s suit had also asked the district court judge to rule ranked-choice voting unconstitutional
column11: and in a statement after Thursday morning’s ruling

column14: one-vote’ first choice election on Election Day that has been used in Maine for more than one hundred years
column15: ” Poliquin said. “We will proceed with our constitutional concerns about the rank vote algorithm.” Golden
column16: the state House Assistant Majority Leader
column17: is a Marine veteran who served in Iraq and Afghanistan. The Leeds native
column18: a former committee staffer to GOP Sen. Susan Collins
column19: represents part of Lewiston-Auburn
column20: an old mill town on the Androscoggin River that makes up the major population center of the district. Democrats held the 2nd District in northern Maine for 20 years before Poliquin flipped the seat when it opened in 2014. He defeated Democrat Emily Cain. Despite heavy spending against him
column21: he defeated Cain by an even bigger margin in 2016 when Trump picked off an electoral vote from the district. No incumbent has lost the 2nd District since 1916. By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman President Trump’s $1.5 trillion tax cut was supposed to be a big selling point for congressional Republicans in the midterm elections. Instead
column2: it appears to have done more to hurt
column3: than help
column4: Republicans in high-tax districts across California
column5: New Jersey
column6: Virginia and other states. House Republicans suffered heavy Election Day losses in districts where large concentrations of taxpayers claim a popular tax break — the state and local tax deduction — which the law capped at $10
column7: 000 per household. The new limit resulted in an effective tax increase for high-earning residents of high-tax states who claim more than $10
column8: 000 per year in SALT. Democrats swept four Republican-held districts in Orange County
column9: Calif.

column11: defeating a pair of Republican incumbents and winning seats vacated by Representatives Ed Royce and Darrell Issa. Those districts include longtime Republican strongholds
column12: like Newport Beach
column13: and rank among the country’s largest users of the state and local tax break. Representative Barbara Comstock lost a seat in Northern Virginia
column14: where more than half of taxpayers claim the SALT deduction
column15: by nearly 13 points. Representative Erik Paulsen of Minnesota
column16: a huge champion of the tax bill
column17: lost by about the same margin in a district where 40 percent of taxpayers claim the deduction. “The state and local tax deduction being capped at $10
column18: 000 hurt a lot of people in our district and our state

column20: a Democrat who won an open seat that was previously held by Mr. Issa
column21: said in an interview shortly before the election. The SALT cap may not have been the primary motivation for voters in choosing Democratic candidates. But a review of polling data over the past year suggests that the limit has some key Republican constituencies feeling bittersweet about the new law — and more willing to back Democrats in House elections. New Jersey Democrats wasted little time after the election to begin pushing to lift the SALT cap. On Monday
column22: Representatives Bill Pascrell and Josh Gottheimer called for reinstatement of the full deduction
column23: in a news conference in front of a salt depot in Ramsey
column24: N.J. Before the new law
column25: taxpayers could deduct the full amount of state and local taxes — including income and property taxes — they paid each year from their federal tax returns. The deduction particularly benefits high earners who are more likely to itemize their deductions
column26: instead of claiming the standard deduction. And it tends to benefit taxpayers in more liberal states
column27: like New York and California
column28: where tax rates are often higher. It also costs the federal government billions of dollars each year and lawmakers looked to limit the tax break to help pay for the $1.5 trillion tax cut. The cap is expected to generate about $70 billion per year
column29: according to the Tax Policy Center. In their first draft of a tax bill last year
column30: House Republicans proposed to scrap the deduction entirely. That caused an outcry from several Republican lawmakers who represent high-tax districts in New Jersey and California. Even after party leaders offered the $10
column31: 000 cap as a compromise
column32: several of those Republicans voted against the final bill
column33: saying it would raise taxes for their constituents. Representative Dana Rohrabacher of California
column34: in an op-ed column explaining his ‘no’ vote
column35: said that the law “would raise taxes for many of my constituents.” Representative John J. Faso of New York complained in a news release that the SALT cap “impacts New York families more severely than those in other states.” Mr. Rohrabacher and Mr. Faso lost their seats
column36: as did Leonard Lance of New Jersey
column37: who similarly voted against the tax bill. The law
column38: as enacted
column39: cuts taxes for most Americans in the first year. But about two million Americans who claim more than $10
column40: 000 a year under SALT will see a net tax increase this year from the law
column41: according to the independent Tax Policy Center in Washington. They account for about 1 percentage point of the 6.3 percent of taxpayers who will see a tax increase this year from the changes to the individual tax code
column42: the center’s data shows. Analyses suggest that group skews heavily toward households earning $200
column43: 000 or more. In the months leading up to the election
column44: the online research platform SurveyMonkey interviewed nearly 30
column45: 000 registered voters about their opinions on the tax law
column46: their voting intentions and other topics. A New York Times analysis of that data suggests that the cap on the SALT deduction may have had a significant effect on voters’ views of the tax law — and perhaps even on how they voted. Voters in areas where a large share of households take the SALT deduction were significantly more likely to say that they opposed the tax law. That was true even controlling for factors like education
column47: income and partisanship. Even among Republicans
column48: the tax law was significantly less popular in ZIP codes where a large share of households took the SALT deduction in 2016. Voters in those areas were also more likely to say they planned to support Democratic candidates in the midterms

column50: such as education
column51: gender and race had a far bigger impact.) By contrast
column52: there is essentially no evidence that other elements of the tax law helped Republicans. Republican incumbents fared no better in districts where voters got larger tax cuts

column6: Calif. — It was 90 degrees that afternoon
column7: but at a rest stop along Interstate 5 in the mountains of Northern California
column8: it snowed flakes of ash on my pickup. The wildfire raging nearby was about as bad as anyone could imagine
column9: but our imaginations hadn’t reached November yet. This was August
column10: long before we lost Paradise and much of Malibu
column11: before the fiery hellscapes at opposite ends of a state under siege lit up screens around the world. This was before the long-fading myth of California as Eden was scorched into some sort of Mad Max dystopia
column12: before teams of forensic examiners were sent to sift through the ashes to find the dozens
column13: maybe hundreds
column14: of missing dead. It was when there was still hope that the latest big fire would be the last one to worry about for a while. The hot
column15: smoky summer air smelled like campfire. A worried asthmatic woman headed to San Diego asked me when it would end. Other side of Redding
column16: I said. I wasn’t sure. Maybe Sacramento. Just keep going. The Carr Fire burned for six weeks and scorched about 230
column17: 000 acres — a bigger area than the five boroughs of New York City combined. It destroyed about 1
column18: 600 buildings and killed at least three people. Its smoke carried halfway across the country
column19: proving that California’s influence spreads in peculiar ways. I followed the woman south through the mountains and soon spotted something moving under a long bridge
column20: below the choking haze. Down on Lake Shasta
column21: there were boaters and water skiers. I laughed. That’s so California
column22: I thought. Heavenly and hellish
column23: sometimes simultaneously. It’s after Election Day now. The Camp Fire in Butte County is now California’s deadliest ever
column24: and the Woolsey Fire in and around Malibu chased out a quarter-million evacuees in its first days. I live in the Bay Area
column25: nowhere near the fires but persistently reminded of them. My neighborhood slinks through the rugged hills of dry grass and trees
column26: terrain not unlike what we’ve seen burning on television. It hasn’t rained in six weeks; before that
column27: not since spring. The toxic drift from the Camp Fire has made our air so murky that schools closed. Ash falls again on my truck

column29: deadly and costly forest fires in California except that forest management is so poor
column30: ” Trump wrote
column31: finding little use for empathy or truth. “Billions of dollars are given each year
column32: with so many lives lost
column33: all because of gross mismanagement of the forests. Remedy now
column34: or no more Fed payments!” It was the latest in a series of perplexing verbal missives aimed at California. Californians know all about outsider ambivalence toward the Golden State. It has been going on for generations. Love it or hate it. Now those feelings have spread wide and deep into the national political discourse. All across the country
column35: California represents a foil for people who worry that it foreshadows the future of the country
column36: as it always has. “Are we going to turn into California?” one candidate for governor in Nevada said in October

column40: post-election

column42: the recent setting of another unexplained mass shooting
column43: a place with both abject poverty and astronomical housing costs
column44: everyone waiting for the big earthquake. Funny
column45: I think
column46: every time I hear California insulted. I choose to live here. There is no other place I’d rather raise my children. I’m always proud to say I’m from California
column47: a beautiful and messy place unlike any other
column48: in a moment unlike any other. One in eight Americans live here. If California were a country
column49: it would represent the world’s fifth-biggest economy. It is the most diverse state in the country
column50: by measures of geography
column51: economy
column52: culture and demographics. Always a trendsetter
column53: California today is the United States of tomorrow. That scares plenty of people. It relieves others. California has a unique combination of influence and ambition

column57: 000 miles away. California already has sued the Trump administration 44 times

column59: health care

column63: if I thought that was the point. I bemoan the ever-worsening traffic. I’m aghast at the levels of homelessness. I’m disappointed in the public schools. I bought my house six years ago

But for years
column65: more people have left California than moved into it from other states. Most of us are digging in. It’s exciting to be on the front lines to many of this country’s biggest problems — climate change and energy

The Tubbs Fire was just one of several that broke out in little-known corners of wine country late that night. I live about 30 miles south of Santa Rosa. I had returned home the night before

column112: because my best friend used to live there. The night after the shooting

column1: ---split---3.0---split---https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/white-house-jim-acostas-press-pass-cnn-seeks/story?id=59291734---split---The Trump White House in a letter says it is dropping its effort to suspend the press pass belonging to CNN's chief White House correspondent Jim Acosta but has outlined a set of rules that
column2: if they aren't followed
column3: "may result in suspension or revocation" of a journalist's press pass. "Your hard pass is restored
column4: White House press secretary Sarah Sanders and deputy chief of staff for communications Bill Shine wrote to Acosta. Should you refuse to follow these rules in the future
column5: we will take action in accordance with the rules
column6: they wrote after outlining the rules. Trump was aware of this decision and concurs
column7: according to the letter. Following the letter from the White House Monday afternoon, CNN dropped the case in court. Today the White House fully restored Jim Acosta's press pass. As a result
column8: our lawsuit is no longer necessary. We look forward to continuing to cover the White House
column9: CNN said in a statement. The letter from the White House outlines four rules: a journalist will ask a single question and then will yield the floor to other journalists
column10: follow-up questions will be permitted at the discretion of the president or other White House officials taking questions
column11: yielding the floor" is defined as "physically surrendering" the microphone and
column12: lastly
column13: "failure to abide" by any of the rules may result in "suspension or revocation of the journalist's hard pass." Acosta was stripped of his press pass without warning earlier this month after a heated exchange during a press conference with President Donald Trump one day after the midterm elections. His press pass was temporarily restored by a court order Friday and the judge ordered both legal teams to submit a status report detailing how they would like to proceed by 3 p.m. on Monday. The Friday ruling guaranteed Acosta use of his press pass to the White House through the end of the month. But over the weekend
column14: the White House wasted no time informing Acosta of a “preliminary decision” to suspend his pass after that period is up. Lawyers for CNN responded Monday by filing for an emergency hearing the week after Thanksgiving
column15: “or as soon thereafter as possible.”   The letter cites “behavior” at a press conference the day after the midterms that “violated the basic standards governing such events” as the reason to suspend Acosta’s pass. It’s signed by Bill Shine
column16: deputy chief of staff for communications
column17: and Sarah Sanders
column18: White House press secretary
column19: who are both named as defendants in the initial lawsuit. Over the weekend
column20: Acosta and CNN’s legal team wrote back to Sanders and Shine
column21: calling the letter an “attempt to provide retroactive due process” and requesting the White House “refrain from — yet again — violating the constitutional rights of CNN and Acosta.” In the letter
column22: Acosta wrote that there were "no so-called 'widely understood practices'" governing press conferences
column23: which the White House jumped on in outlining four rules on Monday.   CNN filed a lawsuit earlier this week claiming that revoking Acosta's press pass to the White House
column24: known as a "hard pass
column25:
violated the First Amendment.   U.S. District Judge Timothy J. Kelly repeatedly emphasized at the court hearing on Friday that his decision to return Acosta's press pass, with a temporary restraining order as litigation continues, was based on the Fifth Amendment, under which the judge ruled Acosta was denied his right to due process. Due process would give Acosta and CNN the chance to rebut and challenge the appropriateness of the government’s action. In his closing remarks, Kelly made clear that the ruling, which is only the beginning of the court proceedings to decide Acosta’s White House access, was narrow and didn’t determine whether or not Acosta’s First Amendment right was violated. ABC News' Jonathan Karl contributed to this report.
---split---3.0---split---https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/note-mississippi-runoff-tests-democrats-momentum/story?id=59282557---split---The TAKE with Rick Klein Overtime is over in Georgia and Florida now after Democrats ran out of options -- and are short of votes -- in both southern states. That leaves Mississippi looming as a challenge and an opportunity for a party that wants to show it can compete everywhere, and win, even where it's not supposed to. There are a few reasons to think that the Mississippi Senate runoff, scheduled for the Tuesday after Thanksgiving, would offer the right mix of circumstances for a Democratic upset. Democrat Mike Espy only advanced to this round of voting because the two major Republicans split votes two weeks ago. But Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith, R-Miss., has made a series of public statements that raise the stakes on matters of race and voting rights. The issues are all too familiar for Democrats after campaigns that fell short in Georgia and Florida. Sen. Kamala Harris, D-Calif., campaigned for Espy over the weekend, calling out racism
column26: anti-Semitism
column27: sexism
column28: homophobia." Sen. Cory Booker
column29: D-N.J.
column30: will campaign in the state on Monday and President Donald Trump will stump for Hyde-Smith next week
column31: on the eve of the runoff. The race is sufficiently nationalized at this point. Democrats who want to sustain momentum from Election Day will face an early -- if not entirely fair -- test.   The RUNDOWN with MaryAlice Parks After visiting literal scorched earth in California this weekend
column32: Trump cooled his usual slash-and-burn politics. California Gov. Jerry Brown said Sunday the president had the state's residents' backs. After first threatening to pull federal funding to the state
column33: the president since promised to send emergency aid. Brown praised the decision. "In the face of tragedy
column34: people tend to rise above some of their lesser propensities
column35: Brown said on CBS's Face the Nation. So I think we're on a good path." The president received strong rebukes for his initial comments about land mismanagement
column36: given the Republican Party's silence on climate change and the fact that the federal government actually owns and controls a significant majority of California's forests.   The TIP with John Verhovek The area once referred to by President Ronald Reagan as the place where "good Republicans go to die" and the home Richard Nixon's presidential library will have no Republican members of Congress come January 2019. Before 2016
column37: Orange County
column38: California
column39: hadn't voted for a Democratic presidential candidate since the Great Depression. And in 2018
column40: Democrats flipped four OC-based congressional districts on their way to reclaiming the House majority. Democrats hold 45 of California's 53 seats in the U.S. House
column41: and those members now compose nearly 20 percent of the entire Democratic caucus. The result is a testament to Democrats' efforts in the area during June's jungle primary
column42: where they spent millions to ensure that despite all candidates running on one ballot regardless of party
column43: they were not locked out of the general election. It is also undeniably a sign of the shifting political ground in many parts of the country. "America used to be a country of regional parties within each party
column44: while both parties are on the path of losing this important representation
column45: the path of the GOP is nearly complete to a nationalized ideological right-wing party

column1: ---split---3.0---split---https://abcnews.go.com/Politics/trumps-appointment-matthew-whitaker-acting-attorney-general-unconstitutional/story?id=59279730---split---The top Democrat on the House Intelligence Committee said President Donald Trump’s appointment of Matthew Whitaker as acting attorney general was unconstitutional because the attorney general is a “principal officer” and those positions require Senate confirmation under the Constitution. “I think the appointment is unconstitutional
column2: ” Rep. Adam Schiff of California told “This Week” co-anchor Martha Raddatz in an interview Sunday morning. “He is clearly a principal officer and the fact that he is a temporary principal officer doesn't mean that that is any less subject to Senate confirmation.” “Will Democrats still challenge that appointment and are you concerned about him overseeing the Mueller investigation?” Raddatz asked Schiff. “Yes and yes
column3: ” said Schiff
column4: who will be the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee in the new Congress. “When you have a specific statute that says this is the succession plan and doesn't say you can also use the Vacancies Act to avoid the succession plan
column5: you go with the specific statute
column6: ” Schiff said.     The president took to Twitter early Sunday afternoon to respond to Schiff’s criticism
column7: pointing out that Mueller had not been approved by the Senate. Trump also misspelled Schiff's name in the tweet.  So funny to see little Adam Schitt (D-CA) talking about the fact that Acting Attorney General Matt Whitaker was not approved by the Senate
column8: but not mentioning the fact that Bob Mueller (who is highly conflicted) was not approved by the Senate!  "Wow
column9: Mr. President
column10: that’s a good one. Was that like your answers to Mr. Mueller’s questions
column11: or did you write this one yourself?" Schiff replied on Twitter
column12: referencing a statement Trump made Friday about his written answers to the special counsel. "I write the answers. My lawyers don't write answers
column13: the president said during a cybersecurity initiative bill signing in the Oval Office. I was asked a series of questions
column14: I answered them very easily." The White House has not responded to an ABC News request for comment.     During his interview with Raddatz
column15: Schiff called Whitaker's appointment flawed. “The biggest flaw from my point of view is that he was chosen for the purpose of interfering with the Mueller investigation
column16: ” he said.   Because Whitaker has publicly criticized Mueller’s investigation in the past
column17: including in an August 2017 op-ed for CNN
column18: Schiff said that “ethically he should have absolutely nothing to do with the investigation.” While Schiff is a frequent critic of the president’s
column19: some Republicans have doubted whether Whitaker is right to permanently lead the Justice Department.   In a separate interview on “This Week
column20: ” Sen. Roy Blunt
column21: who serves as the Vice Chairman of the U.S. Senate Republican Conference
column22: said he didn’t think Whitaker should be attorney general. “I don't know Matt Whitaker well
column23: ” Blunt told Raddatz. “On the occasions I've had with him to be -- he's been very responsive and has seen that the Justice Department responded to the things I've asked about. So in terms of an acting capacity
column24: he does not -- he seems to be a person that has the ability to do that acting job.”   “But not a permanent position; is that what you're saying?” Raddatz pressed. “Well
column25: I would think -- I -- I would think not. But that's -- the president needs to determine who's going to be permanently at the Justice Department as soon as he can
column26: ” he said.
