column5: no matter how desperate they get). Indeed
column6: a lot of what people were talking about last week—Melania Trump's verion of "you're fired" and pro wrestling debacles aside—were events set in motion at various points in the past. But perhaps we shouldn’t be surprised that this week ended up being far less original than it might otherwise have been. It did
column7: after all
column8: start with the sad death of Marvel co-creator Stan Lee; you can’t blame the universe’s creativity for being a little low after that

column10: Donald Trump managed to shun them not once

column14: it was that he was running toward commemorating all the American soldiers who died in Europe during the Great War. There was just one problem with that: He ended up skipping a planned visit to the Aisne-Marne American Cemetery on Saturday
column15: with the cancellation officially blamed on “scheduling and logistical difficulties caused by the weather.” https://twitter.com/FHeisbourg/status/1061268124899729408 https://twitter.com/kurteichenwald/status/1061487951111168000 https://twitter.com/ClaraJeffery/status/1061364708920320000 He did
column16: at least
column17: show up for a second cemetery visit a day later (but only after being pals with Vladimir Putin
column18: because of course). At least that didn’t backfire
column19: right? https://twitter.com/WestWingReport/status/1061648075578576902 https://twitter.com/stevennelson10/status/1061639491113365509 https://twitter.com/lizziedearden/status/1061639791069007873 He returned to the US that day
column20: in time to be observe Veterans Day in Washington
column21: meaning he can uphold that proud tradition of visiting Arlington National Cemetery. Because
column22: surely
column23: after what happened in France
column24: he’d not skip that for any reason. (You know what’s coming next.) https://twitter.com/MrFilmkritik/status/1062018694128242688 Oh yes
column25: that happened. https://twitter.com/MikeyKayNYC/status/1062129466556801025 https://twitter.com/repblumenauer/status/1062169154533408768 Well
column26: if he wasn’t going to Arlington National Cemetery

column28: because he himself brought it up on Twitter later in the week: https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1062371844836261891 Sure

column32: and—like most true horror—infinitely more mundane: https://twitter.com/ErickFernandez/status/1062884472884994048 What Happened: In the face of an attack on the First Amendment by the United States Government
column33: CNN did something unexpected: It took the matter to the courts
column34: suing the White House for shutting out reporter Jim Acosta. Where It Blew Up: Twitter
column35: media reports What Really Happened: Perhaps you remember last week
column36: when the White House decided to pull CNN reporter Jim Acosta’s pass for reasons that were immediately contradicted by anyone with access to un-doctored video. This week
column37: there was a surprise when CNN went surprisingly hard in response: https://twitter.com/CNNPR/status/1062349001285079040 https://twitter.com/brianstelter/status/1062350626389020673 https://twitter.com/ErikWemple/status/1062365023014662145 The lawsuit was
column38: as should only be expected
column39: a huge media story
column40: perhaps

column42: other organizations were much more supportive: https://twitter.com/jdawsey1/status/1062735841926283265 https://twitter.com/grynbaum/status/1062743892435632129 https://twitter.com/brianstelter/status/1062763151115063298 And as it turned out
column43: the White House wasn’t content to let Sarah Huckabee Sanders handle the official response alone: https://twitter.com/CNN/status/1062754556503883776 https://twitter.com/ZoeTillman/status/1062738881693523968 https://twitter.com/MarshallCohen/status/1062758551733657600 On Wednesday

They did not. https://twitter.com/pdmcleod/status/1063452596470538240 https://twitter.com/SchneiderCNN/status/1063453789724831746 https://twitter.com/ACLU/status/1063458045164961793 The Takeaway: More partisan outlets were quick to jump to the administration's defense. Not only did fringe network One America News Network file a brief supporting the White House
column47: but at least one pundit thought this was the best opportunity to own the libs just a little bit more: https://twitter.com/MarkDice/status/1063273834516668417 What Happened: Post-midterms
column48: everyone suddenly remembers that the President of the United States is under a special counsel investigation. And when we say “everyone
column49: ” we mean the President of the United States. Where It Blew Up: Twitter
column50: media reports What Really Happened: This week has been a fascinating one for those who remember the fact that an ongoing investigation is examining whether the Trump campaign colluded with a foreign power to get him elected back in 2016. For one thing
column51: people started to notice some strange social-media patterns: https://twitter.com/martinwalsh/status/1062204473072701440 (For what it’s worth

column53: start conspiring. It should also be noted that WikiLeaks might have an additional reason for being silent if reports are to be believed.) Oh
column54: and then there was a rash of reports—prompted by an associate of Roger Stone—that Robert Mueller was preparing to issue new indictments
column55: potentially including Jared Kushner and Donald Trump Jr.. Against this background

column58: some tried to create legislation to protect Mueller. Any guesses as to how that went? https://twitter.com/igorbobic/status/1062816556521046017 https://twitter.com/MikeDelMoro/status/1062818058337689600 https://twitter.com/jaketapper/status/1062838011820498946 https://twitter.com/LauraLitvan/status/1063149103134183426 Thursday morning
column59: the President did his best impression of someone who almost certainly has nothing to hide and certainly isn’t guilty of anything suspicious that could be uncovered by the Special Counsel investigation on Twitter: https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1063042585802039296 https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1063046973857718272 https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1063081553075625984 https://twitter.com/realDonaldTrump/status/1063084073231544320 It’s worth noting that the rant came not only after Trump had installed Whitaker as acting AG
column60: but also after the President had met with his lawyers to respond to written questions from Mueller. Not that there's
column61: uh
column62: any connection between the two. And then there's the question of the actual contents of the rant: https://twitter.com/jonkarl/status/1063049123346214912 https://twitter.com/oneunderscore__/status/1063043095732912128 https://twitter.com/MaxBoot/status/1063074419571150848 https://twitter.com/ddale8/status/1063087400472207361 The Takeaway: Still
column63: it’s not like the President’s lawyer is making public statements suggesting that the President can’t answer questions without getting in trouble with the law
column64: right? https://twitter.com/jdawsey1/status/1063189614427602944 What Happened: After months of speculation
column65: Amazon finally announced the location—sorry
column66: locations—of its new headquarters. Where It Blew Up: Twitter

column68: New York and Northern Virginia: https://twitter.com/WSJ/status/1062201696393277441 Two headquarters for the price of one! (And what a price

column71: though. Actually

column73: of course: https://twitter.com/bettinajudd/status/1062292667810439168 https://twitter.com/saschasegan/status/1062367581875646465 https://twitter.com/Ocasio2018/status/1062204614496403457 I’m sure that the cost to the cities is entirely necessary and not ridiculously ostentatious
column74: right? https://twitter.com/henrygrabar/status/1062378212859228162 https://twitter.com/davidsirota/status/1062399105031266304 Then again

column76: though: https://twitter.com/NaomiEide/status/1062381106677407745 Oh
column77: and there’s something else strange about the Virginia location… https://twitter.com/brfreed/status/1062358666337271810 https://twitter.com/vikkie/status/1062358896294137856 Wait
column78: it gets better: https://twitter.com/markberman/status/1062362798343286785 Is … is this innovation? The Takeaway: But amidst all of this
column79: let’s take a moment to think about the cities that didn’t win the chance to host Amazon. I bet they’re heartbroken: https://twitter.com/laura_nelson/status/1062365714042912768 What Happened: Meanwhile
column80: in the United Kingdom
column81: the looming shadow of Brexit has gotten a little bit sharper this week
column82: thus making the political future of the woman in charge of the entire country look far more uncertain. Where It Blew Up: Twitter
column83: media reports What Really Happened: Remember Brexit? That whole “Britain voted to leave the European Union
column84: which was a terrible decision
column85: but the people who regretted it weren’t in charge
column86: and now it’s just months away and no one knows how it's going to actually work” thing? Everyone was waiting for the United Kingdom to make a deal with the European Union that was
column87: somehow
column88: agreeable to both parties—something that was beginning to seem impossible
column89: given that it hadn’t happened in the two years since the original vote. And then
column90: this week
column91: a deal finally appeared to be made. A deal that U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May certainly stood behind firmly and strongly: https://twitter.com/christopherhope/status/1062787890558763010 Ah

The opposition parties certainly didn't seem willing to give her the benefit of the doubt: https://twitter.com/PeterAdamSmith/status/1062801122967085056 https://twitter.com/jeremycorbyn/status/1062706734207254529 https://twitter.com/Keir_Starmer/status/1061356393691779072 For her part
column96: May was a touch less than convincing when arguing her case in Parliament: https://twitter.com/BBCNews/status/1063020571590504449 Indeed
column97: she fared so poorly that one of her own MPs threw her under the bus in an impressively public fashion: https://twitter.com/faisalislam/status/1063030974395703297 That’s Jacob Rees Mogg

column100: and not everyone in May’s Conservative party is so desperately unhappy... https://twitter.com/DominicRaab/status/1062992019449098241 https://twitter.com/Aiannucci/status/1063007128645001216 Okay
column101: so the Brexit Secretary quitting in protest is not a good sign. But the resignations had only just begun. https://twitter.com/EstherMcVey1/status/1063008263225126912 https://twitter.com/TeamRanil/status/1063047836055560193 https://twitter.com/Rehman_Chishti/status/1063083736164720640 https://twitter.com/easypoliticsUK/status/1063078298627043328 https://twitter.com/bbcquestiontime/status/1063209929165684736 Well at least this is purely political and doesn't have any real-world implications... https://twitter.com/FinancialTimes/status/1063220136256159744 The Takeaway: Of course
column102: the national mood in the United Kingdom continued to express that stiff upper lip that the union of nations is known for. https://twitter.com/frankieboyle/status/1063051982955573248 Many fake news peddlers didn’t care if Trump won or lost the election. column1: ---split---14.0---split---http://www.pewresearch.org/essay/from-maga-to-metoo-a-look-at-u-s-public-opinion-in-2017/---split---Numbers
column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  December 20
column3: 2017 In his first year as U.S. president
column4: Donald Trump represented a clear break in style and substance from his predecessor
column5: Barack Obama – and from many of the chief executives who came before them. The businessman-turned-politician upended Washington with unrestrained rhetoric and an “America First” agenda that included renegotiating international trade pacts
column6: withdrawing from a worldwide climate change agreement and curtailing immigration into the United States. At home and abroad
column7: the public reacted strongly to the White House’s new occupant and his policies. Confidence in the U.S. president plummeted in many countries
column8: particularly in Western Europe
column9: while opinions of America itself also declined sharply. In the U.S.
column10: already-wide partisan gaps on fundamental political values grew even wider. A fraught relationship between Trump and the press drew frequent attention
column11: with large majorities seeing it as unhealthy and an impediment to Americans’ ability to access important political news. And
column12: as the country began to adjust to this new era
column13: substantial shares in both parties – particularly women – said they were paying more attention to politics since Trump’s election. Democrats were overwhelmingly negative in their assessments of Trump
column14: who came to office vowing to undo Obama-era policies from the 2010 health care overhaul to environmental regulations to a program that shielded nearly 800
column15: 000 young unauthorized immigrants from deportation. Republicans were buoyed by the arrival of the first GOP president in eight years and cheered his successful nomination of Neil Gorsuch to the Supreme Court. While some GOP members of Congress found themselves at odds with an unconventional and outspoken chief executive of their own party
column16: Republicans appeared poised to achieve a major legislative victory at year’s end by overhauling the federal tax code. Trump’s contentious first year was among the defining stories of 2017. But beyond the shifts in policy and approach that accompanied the transition between presidential administrations
column17: the year revealed other important trends shaping American society. Allegations of sexual misconduct against powerful men in entertainment
column18: media and politics – from Hollywood producer Harvey Weinstein to morning news anchor Matt Lauer to the longest-serving member of Congress
column19: John Conyers – brought widespread attention to the issues of sexual harassment
column20: gender discrimination and gender equality. The #MeToo campaign
column21: which spread rapidly on Twitter and Facebook in the wake of these news stories
column22: prompted women around the country to share stories about their personal experiences with sexual misconduct. And
column23: when Time magazine selected its “Person of the Year” in December
column24: the winner was not one person but the broad range of people who came forward. Pew Research Center surveys underscored the breadth of these experiences
column25: as well as the public’s attitudes toward them. In a poll conducted in early fall
column26: about four-in-ten U.S. women said they had personally experienced gender discrimination or been treated unfairly because of their gender
column27: while nearly six-in-ten women said the country hasn’t gone far enough when it comes to giving women equal rights with men. In a separate survey
column28: many employed women reported an array of experiences with gender discrimination at work
column29: ranging from earning less than a man for doing the same job to being treated as if they were not competent. Racial issues continued to draw national attention. The removal of Confederate statues by local governments in the South and elsewhere became a flashpoint as Americans debated whether the statues perpetuated racism or merely reflected a common history. In August
column30: a white nationalist rally in Charlottesville
column31: Virginia
column32: led to violent clashes in the city’s streets
column33: including the death of one person and the injury of 19 others when a car driven by an alleged white nationalist sped into a crowd of counterprotesters. Discussions of race extended to other venues as well. When the NFL season began in the fall
column34: some players protested perceived racial injustice and police mistreatment of blacks by kneeling during the national anthem
column35: a move that provoked anger among those who saw the protests as disrespectful. Trump was among those who criticized the players; indeed
column36: he was a frequent commenter on the nation’s racial controversies. Against this backdrop
column37: the public expressed rising concern about race relations. In an August survey conducted shortly after the violence in Charlottesville
column38: nearly six-in-ten Americans said they viewed racism as a big problem in U.S. society — up 8 percentage points from 2015 and roughly double the share who held this view in November 2011. But there were stark divisions along racial and partisan lines. For example
column39: Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents were far more likely than Republicans and Republican leaners to see racism as a big problem. A similar trend was evident on a separate question about whether white people in the U.S. benefit from societal advantages that blacks do not have: Democrats and Democratic leaners were much more likely than Republicans and GOP leaners to say whites do benefit from such advantages. The economy brought positive news. The national unemployment rate fell to 4.1% in October and November
column40: the lowest level since 2000. The Dow Jones industrial average
column41: which broke 20
column42: 000 points in January for the first time ever
column43: soared to more than 24
column44: 000 points by the end of the year. Americans’ evaluations of the economy also improved: About four-in-ten rated national economic conditions as “excellent” or “good
column45: ” the highest share in a decade. As has historically been the case
column46: however
column47: views tended to be colored by the public’s partisan affiliations
column48: with a surge in Republican optimism driving much of the overall increase in economic positivity. Gun violence took an especially deadly toll in 2017. In October
column49: a gunman in a Las Vegas hotel room opened fire on an open-air concert below
column50: killing 58 people and injuring nearly 500 in the deadliest mass shooting in the country’s modern history. A month later
column51: a man in rural Texas shot 26 people to death and injured 20 others as they attended a Sunday church service – the worst mass shooting in that state’s history. Earlier in the year
column52: a gunman fired dozens of rounds at members of Congress
column53: their staff members and others participating in a morning baseball practice in Alexandria
column54: Virginia
column55: severely injuring Rep. Steve Scalise
column56: one of the highest-ranking members of the House of Representatives. The spate of attacks brought familiar calls for legislation to restrict access to guns. A survey the Center conducted in spring
column57: before the shootings
column58: found areas of agreement on some proposals
column59: such as preventing the mentally ill from purchasing guns and requiring background checks for private gun sales and those at gun shows. More broadly
column60: however
column61: it shed light on the country’s complex relationship with guns
column62: including some fundamental divides between gun owners and non-gun owners and Democrats and Republicans. While three-quarters of Democrats and Democratic leaners said gun laws should be more strict than they are today
column63: for instance
column64: only about a quarter of Republicans and Republican leaners (24%) agreed. And while most Republicans (56%) said there would be less crime if more Americans owned guns
column65: just 15% of Democrats shared that view. Large partisan gaps were evident across many of the issues the Center asked about in 2017
column66: from Trump’s proposed border wall with Mexico to the threat posed by global climate change. One area that starkly divided the parties was the investigation by special counsel Robert Mueller into alleged ties between Trump’s presidential campaign and Russia. The inquiry
column67: launched in May
column68: led to criminal charges against four former members of the campaign
column69: including its one-time chairman
column70: Paul Manafort. In a survey fielded in November and December
column71: only about a quarter of Republicans and Republican leaners (26%) said Trump officials definitely or probably had improper contacts with Russia during the campaign. By contrast

column1: ---split---14.0---split---https://www.foxnews.com/opinion/michael-goodwin-jim-acosta-abused-his-privileges-as-a-member-of-the-press---split---This material may not be published

column5: LLC. All rights reserved. All market data delayed 20 minutes. CNN wins court order against the Trump administration after the White House revoked the CNN reporter's credentials. Just because you can doesn’t mean you should. That age-old advice about the distinction between freedom and wisdom came to mind as I read the ruling that requires the White House to reissue media credentials to CNN blowhard Jim Acosta. Federal Judge Timothy Kelly said Acosta must be allowed to return because there was no due process in the decision to suspend him. Kelly
column6: appointed by President Trump
column7: emphasized he wasn’t ruling on the merits of the suspension or Acosta’s behavior
column8: only the process. “I have not determined that the First Amendment was violated here
column9: ” he wrote
column10: adding that the White House has no obligation to call on Acosta for questions. While the outcome is a setback for Trump
column11: it is also sensible and points the way forward. The president responded by saying his team will draw up rulesrequiring “decorum” and standards of behavior
column12: and predicts ultimate victory. Actually
column13: he’s already won something bigger than the case at hand. He’s established the principle that a press pass is not a license to lecture and hector the president while refusing to yield the microphone
column14: all of which Acosta did. The principle is so obvious it shouldn’t need to be clarified
column15: but written rules are necessary because Acosta abused his privilege. Now the details of the rules must be spelled out to cover any future cases. But there won’t be any future cases — if the press corps get its act together. The White House Correspondents’ Association must find the courage to police the bad apples in its ranks instead of waiting for the government to act
column16: then running to the courts for protection. Recall that Acosta got the boot because he was the rudest and most aggressive lout in the room
column17: but was not alone in trashing decorum. For two years
column18: members of the Trump-hating press have used televised briefings and press conferences as a stage to let the world know how they feel about the president. While most reporters ask real questions
column19: even pointed ones
column20: Acosta and his ilk are engaged in a performance art that amounts to virtue signaling to their bosses and colleagues. “Look at me
column21: ” they seem to say. “I’m fighting back.” But it’s not the job of reporters to fight back. Theirs is to gather information
column22: fairly and accurately
column23: and let readers and viewers decide what to do with it. I know how quaint that sounds. But following that tried-and-true formula is how the media built its credibility. The abandonment of decorum is part of the abandonment of standards and is destroying public trust. Over and over
column24: Acosta makes himself the story
column25: which is not appealing
column26: even for some anti-Trumpers. This was hardly the first time Acosta starred in his own drama. Over and over
column27: he makes himself the story
column28: which is not appealing
column29: even for some anti-Trumpers. Indeed
column30: the response to my column supporting the initial suspension reveals that Americans on both sides of the Trump line believe manners still matter. They differ over who is at fault
column31: with Trump supporters seeing most journalists as Democrats with press passes
column32: while Acosta supporters mostly argue he was justified in behaving badly because Trump does
column33: too. As reader Dave Druten put it
column34: “Respecting a president is preferred conduct
column35: but kowtowing to a proven liar is not proper journalism. You need to address the root of the problem and not the symptoms of disrespect it has spawned.” Reader Deanne Payne offers yet another view
column36: saying that
column37: although she is not a Trump supporter
column38: she is disturbed by media bias and the lack of professionalism. “I am a nurse and I care for people of all walks of life and my biases
column39: as part of my job
column40: have to be checked at the door
column41: ” she writes. “The approach by many in the media is undignified and disgraceful.” Payne is on to something
column42: both in moral and practical terms. The idea of using someone else’s conduct to justify your misconduct is childish. Go to any playground and you’ll hear a chorus of “he started it” defenses. It’s simply laughable when adults use that lame excuse
column43: which is what Acosta and his defenders are doing. As for the practical fallout
column44: there are good reasons why trust of the press is at an all-time low. The 2016 election was in part a referendum on the elite media’s disdain for Trump and his supporters. For many of them
column45: conduct like Acosta’s confirms Trump’s “fake news” charges because they see in him the kind of journalist they do not trust to tell the truth. And with surveys consistently showing 90 percent of presidential coverage is negative
column46: it is hard to fault their conclusion. Besides
column47: the president
column48: like all Americans
column49: enjoys First Amendment rights
column50: and nothing in the oath of office requires him to suffer an unfair beating in silence. Still
column51: instead of engaging in endless combat with press-pass partisans
column52: Trump has other options. He could bar cameras at the daily briefings and without a TV audience
column53: the Acosta types would be unlikely to don their Superman capes. Trump could also reduce the frequency of the briefings or cancel them entirely. He could substitute more one-on-one interviews for press conferences. He could
column54: in fact
column55: shun the media altogether because none of these traditions of contact are fundamental or even tangential to freedom of the press. The First Amendment is a key to American liberty in glorious ways
column56: but it is not an excuse for bad manners. It is a tragedy of our era that the media must be reminded of that common-sense truth. To continue reading Michael Goodwin on The New York Post click here. This material may not be published

column33: Leahy said his party was ready to talk more broadly about additional border security needs. “I’m willing to make some compromises provided we can get it done
column34: ” he said. But Leahy hinted that Democrats are ready to play a little “Art of the Deal” themselves if Trump makes some other concessions. “I’d want to see where it’s being spent . . . I can’t speak for my whole caucus
column35: but there are a whole lot of aspects that are involved here
column36: not the least of which are all the poison-pill riders in the House bill
column37: ” Leahy said. His comments echo Senate Minority Leader Charles E. Schumer
column38: D-N.Y.
column39: who said last week he’d had “great discussions” on border security already with the other top Hill leaders of both parties. “I would hope that the president wouldn’t interfere and we would get something good done
column40: ” Schumer said. Where the money will come from to get $5 billion
column41: whether for the wall itself or some other border infrastructure
column42: is anyone’s guess. And it’s part of the reason why the House held back the four-bill spending package — consisting of the fiscal 2019 Agriculture
column43: Interior-Environment
column44: Financial Services and Transportation-HUD measures — after Senate negotiators were ready to sign off in late September. The problem is that Trump has already signed into law five spending bills
column45: which limits the money available under the discretionary caps for fiscal 2019. About 97 percent of the remainder
column46: or $305 billion
column47: is for nondefense programs
column48: according to CQ calculations based on Congressional Budget Office estimates. That includes most of the Homeland Security Department
column49: including CBP and Immigration and Customs Enforcement. The House versions of the seven remaining bills already start out at a deficit; they are $736 million over the $597 billion nondefense cap
column50: according to the CBO. In other words
column51: if the bills were enacted as the House has drafted them
column52: the Office of Management and Budget within 15 days would have to order an across-the-board cut to every nonexempt program to eliminate the excess. The four bills currently in conference hover around the $154 billion mark for both chambers’ versions. The Senate versions are a combined $481 million above the House’s
column53: however — money which could be reserved for the wall. Going down to the lowest amount either chamber has passed for each of the titles would free up even more. But then priorities ranging from food safety inspection to infrastructure would get shortchanged. Either way
column54: it begs the question of why Trump would sign the four-bill package and take money off the table that he thinks could be better spent along the border. And then there are the three remaining bills that have not advanced to the floor of either chamber: Homeland Security
column55: Commerce-Justice-Science and State-Foreign Operations. Using the lower House numbers for the latter two measures would free up an additional nearly $1.1 billion that could be put towards border security if the negotiations were opened up to encompass all seven outstanding fiscal 2019 bills. All told
column56: shaving the remaining allocations for the seven bills down to the lowest of either chamber’s version would free up room for north of $4 billion in wall money — not quite Trump’s demand
column57: but enough to say he got a pretty good deal. The other option is a continuing resolution for some or all of the remaining bills
column58: which could make room for up to $11.2 billion in nondefense savings that could be used for some pretty sizable funding “anomalies
column59: ” including billions in wall funding. Conservatives would get a big win
column60: and Trump would get his wall. But the Census Bureau would be deprived of money needed to conduct the 2020 Census
column61: for instance. On what planet would Democrats agree to shortchanging their own domestic priorities in such a fashion
column62: especially after last week’s midterm results? The best option
column63: at least from the standpoint of appropriators and the federal agencies they provide money for
column64: would be to wrap all seven remaining fiscal 2019 bills before the 115th Congress adjourns. That could involve splitting the funding differences between the chambers and getting somewhere into the $3 billion ballpark for the wall
column65: or around double the previous fiscal year. There is some confidence an outcome like that can be achieved. But as always with the last legislative train leaving the station
column66: appropriators also recognize there are higher powers at work. “Appropriators left to their own devices will get to a deal. The real question is will they be left to their own devices
column67: ” House Appropriations Labor-HHS-Education Subcommittee Chairman Tom Cole
column68: R-Okla.
column69: said. Get breaking news alerts and more from Roll Call on your iPhone or your Android. THE SOURCE FOR NEWS ON CAPITOL HILL SINCE 1955 Want insight more often?  Get Roll Call in your inbox  ×

column5: LLC. All rights reserved. All market data delayed 20 minutes.  Sunday may be a day of rest for a lot of people – but it clearly wasn't this week for President Trump. In an interview on “Fox News Sunday
column6: ” the president addressed a range of topics – including the behavior of CNN correspondent Jim Acosta and his appointment of acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker. He also answered questions about this month’s elections
column7: his written responses to Special Counsel Robert Mueller and foreign policy concerns regarding North Korea
column8: Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. But the president also had an active day on Twitter
column9: starting off with a highly noticed critique of a frequent Trump critic
column10: U.S. Rep. Adam Schiff
column11: D-Calif. “So funny to see little Adam Schitt (D-CA) talking about the fact that Acting Attorney General Matt Whitaker was not approved by the Senate
column12: but not mentioning the fact that Bob Mueller (who is highly conflicted) was not approved by the Senate!” Trump wrote

column24: ” in a taped interview with host Chris Wallace
column25: Trump was able to go beyond the confines of Twitter’s 280-character limit to share his thoughts on a variety of recent topics. Here are some highlights: On CNN’s Jim Acosta: Trump said CNN’s White House correspondent was “unbelievably rude to [White House Press Secretary] Sarah Huckabee” during a recent press briefing. Although a judge recently ordered that Acosta’s revoked White House press pass be returned
column26: if he misbehaves

On acting Attorney General Matthew Whitaker: Trump told Wallace he was unaware of Whitaker’s past remarks about the Mueller investigation into possible collusion between the Trump campaign and Russia when he appointed Whitaker to replace Jeff Sessions at the Department of Justice. I did not know that
column29: Trump said, when asked if he was aware prior to appointing him that Whitaker had argued Mueller was coming close to exceeding his authority. I did not know he took views on the Mueller investigation as such.” On GOP election wins in Florida: "Look at Florida
column30: Trump said. I went down to Florida. [GOP Senate candidate] Rick Scott won
column31: and he won by a lot. I don’t know what happened to all those votes that disappeared at the very end. And if I didn’t put a spotlight on that election before it got down to the 12

column34: OK? In my opinion he would have lost. They would have taken that election away from him. Rick Scott won Florida.” "Rick Scott won

In my opinion he would have lost.” On North Korea: Trump told Wallace that former President Barack Obama had offered him some important guidance in the White House shortly after his 2016 election. “I think North Korea’s been very tough because you know we were very close. When I took that over -- President Obama right in those two chairs
column39: we sat and talked and he said that’s by far the biggest problem that this country has
column40: Trump said. And I think we had real decision as to which way to go on North Korea and certainly at least so far I’m very happy with the way we went." On Saudi Arabia: "You saw we put on very heavy sanctions
column41: massive sanctions on a large group of people from Saudi Arabia
column42: Trump said. But at the same time we do have an ally and I want to stick with an ally that in many ways has been very good.” On Pakistan: “We give Pakistan $1.3 billion a year . ... [bin Laden] lived in Pakistan
column43: we’re supporting Pakistan

column45: by the way. I ended it because they don’t do anything for us
column46: they don’t do a damn thing for us.” Finally … Trump sounded a note of regret for not visiting Arlington National Cemetery on Veterans Day. "I should have done that

column1: ---split---17.0---split---https://www.foxnews.com/politics/down-to-the-wire-why-arent-democrats-overwhelming-favorites---split---This material may not be published
column2: broadcast
column3: rewritten
column4: or redistributed. ©2018 FOX News Network
column5: LLC. All rights reserved. All market data delayed 20 minutes. 'MediaBuzz' host Howard Kurtz weighs in on why
column6: if Donald Trump is such a terrible president
column7: the Democrats aren't the overwhelming favorites in the midterm elections. As the media are awash in predictions and prognostications about today's elections
column8: one question I find fascinating is this: Why haven't the Democrats run away with this thing? After all
column9: if Donald Trump is as terrible a president as the press has been proclaiming for nearly two years
column10: the opposition party should be riding a wave of revulsion to victory. The Dems are favored to win the 23 seats needed to win the House
column11: and some pundits are saying they'll take considerably more
column12: but the fact that even the minimum outcome is in doubt shows a far more competitive election than was forecast a month or two ago. So perhaps Trump
column13: and the Republican candidates following his lead
column14: are better at electoral politics than the wise guys thought. And you can't blame it all on "fear-mongering
column15: even though the president has chosen to close on immigration rather than the booming economy. There is no question that these midterms are largely about Trump, and that he has quite consciously ensured that his name is virtually, though not literally, on the ballot. A provocative theory comes from Ross Douthat, the conservative New York Times columnist and a sharp Trump critic. He cites the often-vast gulf" between "the hysteria of liberals who write about politics for a living and the relative calm of Democrats who practice it." He says that on liberal Twitter
column16: democracy itself hangs in the balance "and every Trump provocation a potential Reichstag fire. But on the campaign trail
column17: with some exceptions and variations
column18: Democrats are being upbeat and talking about health care and taxes and various ambitious policy ideas
column19: as though this is still America and not Weimar
column20: a normal time and not a terrifying one." Maybe the liberal pundits are saying things that the politicians can't
column21: but Douthat argues the Democrats are very lucky. If Trump had governed like a "generic Republican
column22: he'd be more popular and the Democrats would be toast. And if Trump had followed through on the populist promises of 2016, Douthat says, this strategy could have easily cut the knees out from under the Democrats' strongest appeal
column23: their more middle-class-friendly economic agenda
column24: and highlighted their biggest liability
column25: which is the way the party's base is pulling liberalism way left of the middle on issues of race and culture and identity." In this view
column26: Trump drives liberals crazy with his culture war and Twitter crusades
column27: but this in turn lets the Democrats off the hook. I'd be cautious about even the smart analysts who say if only Trump had done this or that
column28: he'd be in a stronger position. Who among them thought Trump would ever win the White House? He has a gut feeling about elections
column29: and while it's fine to criticize his tone
column30: language and choice of subjects
column31: he may well be right that warning about illegal immigration gets more Republicans to the polls than boasting about last year's tax cut. A more vociferous Never-Trumper
column32: NYT conservative Bret Stephens
column33: says the president may have outwitted the opposition by pounding away at the caravan: "To which the Democratic response is — what
column34: exactly? "If it’s 'compassion
column35: ' it’s a non-answer. If it's to abolish ICE
column36: it's a dereliction of responsibility for governance. If it's to open the border
column37: it is an honest form of political suicide. If it's more trade and foreign aid for Central America
column38: that's a solution for the too-long term. "The truth is that there is no easy fix to the challenge of the caravan
column39: which is why Trump was so clever to make the issue his own and Democrats have been so remiss in letting him have it. The secret of Trump's politics is to mix fear and confidence — the threat of disaster and the promise of protection — like salt and sugar
column40: simultaneously stimulating and satisfying an insatiable appetite." Stephens goes on to attack Trump as a demagogue. But whose fault is it if the Democrats don’t have an effective response? If Nancy Pelosi's party wins the House
column41: the media verdict will be that the Democrats pursued the right strategy and that Trump's immigration-based appeal failed. If Pelosi and company fall short
column42: the media will give them partial blame
column43: but will largely conclude that (as a Washington Post news story put it yesterday) "running a campaign built on blunt
column44: race-based attacks on immigrants and minorities will have been validated." But I come back to my original question: If Trump is as terrible as many pundits say
column45: why aren't the Democrats running away with the election? This material may not be published

column1: ---split---18.0---split---http://www.pewforum.org/2018/07/05/how-does-pew-research-center-measure-the-religious-composition-of-the-u-s-answers-to-frequently-asked-questions/---split---Numbers
column2: Facts and Trends Shaping Your World About Follow  Religion & Public Life We regularly are asked about how we measure religion. Here are answers to some of the questions we get most often. How does Pew Research Center measure the religious identity of survey respondents and the religious composition of the U.S.? Answer: Generally
column3: we rely on respondents’ self-identification. A key question we ask in many surveys is: “What is your present religion
column4: if any? Are you Protestant
column5: Roman Catholic
column6: Mormon
column7: Orthodox such as Greek or Russian Orthodox
column8: Jewish
column9: Muslim
column10: Buddhist
column11: Hindu
column12: atheist
column13: agnostic
column14: something else
column15: or nothing in particular?” Those who answer this question by describing themselves as “Protestant” are categorized as Protestants. Some respondents (roughly one-in-ten or more
column16: on average
column17: in recent surveys) answer the question by volunteering that they are “Christian” or “just Christian
column18: ” and they
column19: too
column20: are categorized as Protestants. Respondents who say they belong to nondenominational Christian churches also go into the broad Protestant category. Those who describe themselves as “Catholic” or “Roman Catholic” are categorized as Catholics. And the large – and growing – number of survey respondents who describe themselves as “atheist
column21: ” “agnostic” or “nothing in particular” are often combined into an umbrella group called the religiously unaffiliated (sometimes also called the religious “nones”). Similarly
column22: those who describe themselves as “Mormon
column23: ” “Orthodox
column24: ” “Jewish
column25: ” “Muslim
column26: ” “Buddhist” or “Hindu” are categorized as such in Pew Research Center reporting. Many Pew Research Center surveys encounter too few respondents from these smaller religious groups to permit analysis of their views and characteristics.1 However
column27: the Center’s larger surveys (like the 35
column28: 000 person U.S. Religious Landscape Study) do make it possible to report on the characteristics of these groups. In addition
column29: the Center has conducted several surveys designed specifically to capture the views of smaller religious groups in the U.S.
column30: including three surveys of U.S. Muslims
column31: a 2013 survey of U.S. Jews
column32: a 2012 survey of Asian Americans (including large samples of Buddhists and Hindus)
column33: and a 2011 survey of U.S. Mormons. Respondents who answer by describing their religion as “something else” are asked to specify further. Many of them provide answers suggesting they belong in one of the existing categories
column34: and they are categorized accordingly. For example
column35: after first saying “something else
column36: ” many respondents specify that they are Baptist
column37: Methodist
column38: Presbyterian
column39: Pentecostal
column40: etc.
column41: and are subsequently categorized as Protestants. Others say they are “LDS” (an abbreviation for the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints) and are coded as Mormons
column42: while still others give a variety of answers (e.g.
column43: “Sunni” or “Sufi”) that indicate they are Muslims. The few remaining respondents (typically 1% or 2% of all respondents) who specify something that does not belong in any of the existing categories (including members of smaller religious groups like Sikhs
column44: Baha’is and Rastafarians
column45: as well as those who say they are “spiritual but not religious” or that they have their “own beliefs”) remain categorized as “something else.” We sometimes use a more expansive definition
column46: which includes not just people who identify religiously with a group
column47: but also those who self-identify culturally or ethnically. For example
column48: the Center’s 2013 survey of U.S. Jews included both respondents who described themselves as Jewish when asked about their religion as well as those who described themselves (religiously) as “atheist
column49: ” “agnostic
column50: ” or “nothing in particular” if they also currently considered themselves Jewish or partially Jewish “aside from religion
column51: ” and they were raised Jewish or had a Jewish parent. Similarly
column52: our 2015 survey of U.S. Catholics and Family Life included analysis of “cultural Catholics” in addition to those who identified as Catholic by religion. Instances of this kind of more expansive approach to defining groups are rare
column53: however
column54: and are clearly noted in our reports. But what about Catholics who don’t attend church? Can someone really be Catholic if they don’t attend Mass regularly? Similarly
column55: what about Mormons who don’t believe in God? Can someone who doesn’t believe in God be Mormon? Answer: In our surveys
column56: members of religious groups are categorized based on their self-identification with the group
column57: not on the basis of their religious beliefs or practices. We do ask about beliefs and practices
column58: but those are separate questions. This allows us to see
column59: for example
column60: that among self-described Catholics
column61: roughly four-in-ten say they attend religious services at least once a week
column62: while a similar share say they attend Mass once or twice a month or a few times a year
column63: and one-in-five say they seldom or never attend Mass. All are categorized as Catholics in the Center’s reports
column64: though in many of our larger surveys
column65: we are able to break down the Catholic category into subgroups and compare Catholics who say they go to Mass weekly with those who attend less often. Defining religious categories on the basis of self-identification has a number of benefits
column66: chief among them that this kind of approach makes it possible to describe the diversity of belief and practice that exists within every religious tradition in the U.S. Some religious traditions are composed of people who overwhelmingly profess to believe in the unique teachings of their faith. For example
column67: the Center’s 2011 survey of U.S. Mormons found that 94% of self-described Mormons believe that the president of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is a prophet of God
column68: and 91% believe that the Book of Mormon was written by ancient prophets and translated by Joseph Smith. The same survey found that 82% of Mormons say religion is very important in their lives
column69: and 77% say they attend religious services on at least a weekly basis. Other religious groups exhibit lower levels of uniformity. For example
column70: Americans who identify as Jewish when asked about their religion are roughly evenly divided between those who say religion is very important in their lives (31%)
column71: those who say it is somewhat important in their lives (35%)
column72: and those who say religion is “not too” or “not at all” important in their lives (33%). Pew Research Center surveys even find that a few self-described atheists say they believe in God or a universal spirit. There are a number of possible explanations for this paradox. Some respondents may identify as atheists because they reject traditional images of God
column73: even though they believe there is some spiritual force in the universe. Others may identify as atheist primarily as a means of registering an objection to organized religion. And a few self-described atheists are unclear on what
column74: exactly
column75: the word “atheist” means. Whatever the explanation
column76: the larger point is that no religious group in the U.S. is a monolith. There is diversity of belief and practice within every religious tradition
column77: and defining religious traditions on the basis of self-identification makes it possible to illustrate the multiplicity of belief and practice inside each group. In short
column78: we do not seek to make any judgments about what characteristics may or may not disqualify someone from a particular group. This can often be a matter of opinion; for example
column79: most U.S. Jews say a person cannot be Jewish if he or she believes Jesus was the messiah
column80: but a substantial minority disagree. As a neutral research organization
column81: Pew Research Center does not take positions on these sorts of debates. Protestants are the single largest religious group in the United States. But Pew Research Center usually disaggregates them into several subgroups (for example
column82: evangelical Protestants
column83: mainline Protestants
column84: black Protestants). How do you do this? Answer: To categorize Protestants into subgroups
column85: we typically choose between two different methods
column86: depending on the survey. In most of our surveys
column87: we employ a self-identification approach
column88: which relies on information about respondents’ race and whether they self-identify as a “born-again or evangelical Christian” to sort them into subgroups. In some of our largest surveys
column89: however
column90: we employ a denominational approach
column91: in which Protestants are sorted into subgroups based on the specific denomination with which they identify. In many of the Center’s surveys
column92: including most of our political polling
column93: respondents are asked the religious identification question described above: “What is your present religion
column94: if any? Are you Protestant
column95: Roman Catholic
column96: Mormon
column97: Orthodox such as Greek or Russian Orthodox
column107: all Christians (including people who identify as any type of Protestant as well as Catholics
column109: etc.) are asked a follow-up question: “Would you describe yourself as a born-again or evangelical Christian
column111: all respondents receive a standard series of demographic questions
column112: including about their race/ethnicity. By combining the answers to all these questions
column113: we generally divide Protestants into three groups. Most Pew Research Center surveys do not obtain enough interviews with Hispanic Protestants or other minority Protestants to be able to analyze them separately. While the self-identification approach outlined above is the way the Center typically analyzes subgroups of Protestants
column114: it is not the only approach used in the Center’s analyses. Specifically
column115: in the Center’s two large Religious Landscape Studies
column116: first conducted in 2007 and then again in 2014
column117: Protestants are categorized into one of three major traditions (evangelicalism
column119: or the historically black Protestant tradition) using a denominational approach.2 The denominational approach employed in the Landscape Studies requires asking a longer series of detailed questions about religious affiliation than can be carried on a typical survey. The first question in the series is identical to the one described above: “What is your present religion
column123: Orthodox such as Greek or Russian Orthodox
column132: Protestants (and those who volunteer that they are “Christian” or “just Christian”) are asked about what denominational family they identify with. Specifically
column137: do you identify with most closely? Just stop me when I get to the right one. Are you Baptist
column143: Church of Christ or Disciples of Christ
column144: Congregational or United Church of Christ
column151: Protestants receive a third question based on their answer to the second question – and sometimes based also on their race. Baptists who are not black
column156: do you identify with most closely? The Southern Baptist Convention
column157: the American Baptist Churches in the U.S.A.
column159: or some other Baptist church?” Baptists who are black are asked
column162: do you identify with most closely? The National Baptist Convention
column164: or some other Baptist church?” Presbyterians of all races are asked: “Which of the following Presbyterian churches
column166: do you identify with most closely? The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.)
column168: or some other Presbyterian church?” And those identifying with other denominational families are asked a similar question tailored specifically to them. (For the full list of the questions asked and their exact question wording
column169: see the Landscape Study questionnaire.) The information gleaned from this series of questions is used to categorize Protestants as members of the evangelical
column171: or historically black Protestant tradition based as much as possible on their specific denominational affiliation
column172: and not on their answers to the born-again/evangelical self-identification question (to the extent it can be avoided).3 When this denominational measurement strategy is employed
column173: evangelicals and mainline Protestants can include nonwhites
column174: and the historically black Protestant tradition can include nonblacks. For example
column175: all people who self-identify with the Southern Baptist Convention are classified as evangelicals (even if they are not white and even if they do not self-identify as born-again or evangelical Christians). All people who identify with the American Baptist Churches in the U.S.A. are categorized as mainline Protestants (even if they do identify as “born-again or evangelical Christians”).4And all people who self-identify with the National Baptist Convention are categorized in the historically black Protestant tradition (even if they are not black).5 Complete details about the denominational approach to categorizing Protestants are available in an appendix to the Religious Landscape Study reports. Despite the detailed religious affiliation questions in the Religious Landscape Studies
column176: many respondents (more than a third of all Protestants in the 2014 study) are either unable or unwilling to describe their specific denominational affiliation.6 For instance
column177: some respondents describe themselves as “just a Lutheran” or “just a Presbyterian” or “just a Methodist.” In these cases
column178: respondents are sorted into one of the three Protestant traditions (evangelical
column180: or historically black Protestant tradition) in two ways: Overall
column181: 38% of Protestants in the 2014 Landscape Study offered a vague denominational identity and were classified
column183: on the basis of their race and/or their answer to the question about whether they identify as a born-again or evangelical Christian. For a discussion of how Protestant groups compare to each other depending on which measurement strategy (the self-identification approach or denominational approach) is employed
column184: see Question 7 below. Aren’t most black Protestants evangelicals? And if so
column185: then why do you analyze them separately in so many reports? Answer: Most nonwhite Protestants (70%)
column187: say “yes” when asked directly whether they consider themselves born-again or evangelical Christians. And in terms of their religious beliefs and practices
column190: a number of important ways in which white evangelicals and evangelical minorities closely resemble each other. For example
column191: 84% of white born-again or evangelical Protestants say religion is very important in their lives
column192: and 88% of nonwhite evangelicals say the same
column193: including 92% of black evangelical Protestants who say this. And more than eight-in-ten white evangelicals say they pray every day (83%)
column194: as do 82% of nonwhite evangelicals (including 84% of black self-identified evangelicals). But while white and nonwhite evangelicals (including black evangelicals) share many religious characteristics in common
column195: they are sharply divided when it comes to politics
column196: and their views about many key social and cultural issues. White evangelicals
column198: are among the most strongly Republican
column199: conservative constituencies in American politics. By contrast
column200: nonwhite evangelicals (especially black evangelicals) are among the most strongly and consistently Democratic groups in the U.S. electorate. Pew Research Center regularly focuses on public opinion on political and cultural topics
column201: and this is why white evangelicals and black Protestants often are examined separately in our reports. When asked directly about their partisan leanings
column202: nearly two-thirds of white evangelical Protestants say they lean toward or identify with the Republican Party
column203: while just 22% lean toward or identify with the Democratic Party (the remaining 13% identify as political independents or with another party and decline to lean toward either the GOP or the Democratic Party). Among nonwhite evangelicals
column204: these figures are reversed; 63% identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party
column205: while just 20% prefer the GOP. The Democratic advantage is especially lopsided among black evangelical Protestants
column206: among whom eight-in-ten (79%) say they identify with or lean toward the Democratic Party
column207: compared with just 10% who prefer the GOP. On this measure
column208: there is no discernible difference between black evangelical Protestants and black non-evangelical Protestants
column209: among whom 80% favor the Democratic Party and just 8% identify with or lean toward the GOP.7 In other words
column211: black evangelicals are much more in line with black non-evangelical Protestants than with white evangelicals.8 The same pattern is evident in voting behavior.9 In pre-election polling conducted during the 2016 presidential election
column212: three-quarters of white evangelical Protestants indicated that they intended to vote for Republican Donald Trump (75%)
column213: compared with just 18% who intended to cast a ballot for Democrat Hillary Clinton. Among nonwhite evangelicals
column215: with 71% expressing support for Clinton and just 22% saying they backed Trump. Among black evangelical Protestants
column217: compared with just 5% who intended to vote for Trump. Whites also express much more affinity for the GOP than do nonwhites among non-evangelical Protestants
column218: though they (white non-evangelical Protestants) are significantly less Republican than are white evangelicals. Nearly half of white non-evangelical Protestants identify with or lean toward the GOP
column219: which is nearly three times the share of nonwhite
column220: non-evangelical Protestants who say the same. And whereas 49% of white non-evangelical Protestants expressed an intention to vote for Trump in the 2016 election
column222: non-evangelical Protestants indicated they intended to vote for Trump. In short
column223: there is no escaping the importance and explanatory power of race when it comes to partisanship and electoral politics. Analyses that explore the link between religion and partisanship or voting without taking race into account would obscure far more than they would illuminate. Doesn’t the strong support that Donald Trump received from white evangelicals suggest that the term “evangelical” is now a political label as much as a religious one? And isn’t it true that among whites
column224: there are lots of self-described evangelicals who actually aren’t very religious
column225: but who call themselves evangelicals just because they’re politically conservative or Republican? Answer: During the 2016 presidential campaign
column226: some commentators expressed surprise at the high level of support Donald Trump received from white evangelical voters
column227: and suggested that Trump’s rise may have been driven in large part by outsized support from evangelicals who are not particularly religious. But the notion that there are large numbers of white evangelicals (however defined) who are not particularly religious is false. Whether evangelicalism is defined by the denominational or the self-identification approach
column228: white evangelicals are among the most religiously observant groups in the population. (For details on the difference between the denominational and the self-identification approach to subdividing Protestants
column229: see Question 3 above.) Under the self-identification approach
column230: 88% of white evangelical Protestants interviewed as part of the 2014 Religious Landscape Study score “high” on an index of religiosity that incorporates indicators of religious attendance
column233: and a self-assessment of religion’s importance in one’s life. While some other religious groups (including Mormons and black Protestants) exhibit similar levels of religiosity
column234: there is no group that exhibits a significantly higher level of religious commitment
column235: and many religious groups exhibit much lower levels of religiosity.10 Under the denominational approach
column236: 83% of white evangelicals score high on the same scale. Have fewer people identified as evangelicals in recent years
column237: in part because of the political connotations of the label? More specifically
column238: are people who dislike President Trump abandoning the “evangelical” label for themselves because of evangelicals’ strong support for Trump? Answer: This is a difficult question to answer directly
column239: in part because a definitive answer would require longitudinal data (that is
column240: the same respondents would be interviewed on multiple occasions so researchers could see how their answers change over time). For the time being
column241: the best we can do is to consider this question in the context of longer-term trends in American religion. Our data show
column243: that the share of Americans who describe themselves as born-again or evangelical Protestants has been fairly stable in recent years. In 2009 (which was the first year Pew Research Center asked its now-standard question about religious identification and conducted most of its surveys in both English and Spanish)
column244: 28% of American adults identified as born-again or evangelical Protestants
column245: and this figure held quite stable through 2015. (Trump declared his candidacy for president on June 16
column248: there appears to have been a slight downturn in the share of Americans who identified as evangelical Protestants
column249: which slipped to 26% in 2017. Surveys conducted thus far in 2018 suggest that the number may have recently rebounded to 27%
column252: to know for sure.11 In short
column253: surveys suggest that the share of self-described born-again or evangelical Protestants in the U.S. is either holding steady or declining very slightly. But even if there has been a slight decline in the share of Americans who identify as evangelical Protestants
column254: it can only be understood against the backdrop of broader trends in American religion. The share of Americans who identify with Christianity writ large has been declining for some time. In 2009
column255: more than three-quarters of U.S. adults (77%) identified with some kind of Christianity
column258: 2% who were Mormon and 1% who identified with Orthodox Christianity. By 2014
column259: the share of adults identifying with Christianity had slipped to 71%. And today
column260: 67% of Americans describe themselves as Christians
column263: 2% who are Mormon and 1% who identify with Orthodox Christianity. In other words
column264: to the extent that there has been a decline in the share of Americans who identify as evangelicals
column265: this is part of a broader shift away from Christianity altogether
column266: and these trends long predate the emergence of Trump as a political force. Also
column267: while the share of U.S. adults who identify with Christianity (including Protestantism) has been declining
column269: the percentage who identify with the “born-again or evangelical” Protestant label is at least as high today (39%) as in 2009 (37%) or in the years immediately prior to Trump’s presidential bid (39% in both 2013 and 2014). This suggests that any decline in the share of born-again or evangelical Protestants in the U.S. population is attributable mainly to the decline in the share of Americans who identify with Christianity
column270: and not to a decline in the share of Christians who identify with the “born-again or evangelical” Protestant label.12 While the share of Americans who describe themselves as born-again or evangelical Protestants is holding steady or perhaps declining very slightly
column271: there has been a more clear-cut decline in the share of U.S. adults who are white born-again or evangelical Protestants. In 2009
column272: 20% of U.S. adults were white born-again or evangelical Protestants. Today
column273: 17% of U.S. adults fit this description. But here again
column274: these trends were underway long before Trump’s emergence on the political scene
column275: and they seem to have more to do with broader trends in American religion (including declines in the share identifying with Christianity) and with broader trends in the racial and ethnic composition of the population (including a decline in the share of all U.S. adults who are white) than they do with abandonment of the “born-again or evangelical” label. In Pew Research Center surveys conducted in 2017 and early 2018
column276: just under two-thirds of all respondents have been white (64%). A decade ago
column278: roughly seven-in-ten U.S. adults were white. As the share of adults who are white declined in recent years
column279: so too did the share of whites who describe themselves as Christians. Today
column280: two-thirds of whites (67%) identify as Christians
column281: down from 77% in 2009. But while whites are declining as a share of the population
column282: and identification with Christianity is declining among whites
column283: the percentage of white Christians who describe themselves as born-again or evangelical Protestants is quite stable. In 2009
column284: 37% of white Christians in the U.S. were born-again or evangelical Protestants. Today
column285: 39% of white Christians describe themselves as born-again or evangelical Protestants. Among white Protestants
column286: the share who currently identify as born-again or evangelical Christians (57%) may appear to be down slightly from its peak in late 2016 (59%). But the percentage of born-again or evangelical Christians among white Protestants is currently on par with estimates from 2014 and
column288: slightly above readings taken in 2009 (53%) and 2011 (51%). These data do not prove that no one has abandoned the “born-again or evangelical” label due to concerns about the association between evangelicalism and support for Trump. There may be individuals who have distanced themselves from the “born-again or evangelical” label for exactly those reasons. And
column290: it is also possible that there are individuals who have come to adopt the “born-again or evangelical” label because of their admiration for Trump and their sense that evangelicals strongly support him. However
column291: there is no evidence in Pew Research Center surveys that a sudden
column292: mass movement away from evangelicalism began during the Trump administration or his presidential election campaign. The share of white born-again or evangelical Christians in the U.S. population has been declining
column293: but this gradual shift seems to be part of long-term religious and demographic changes that have been underway for decades. Whether Trump’s popularity among white evangelicals has hastened (or slowed) this shift is not yet clear. What difference does the choice of approach for measuring Protestantism – denominational vs. self-identification – make for understanding the characteristics of Protestants? Answer: There is substantial overlap
column295: between the denominational and self-identification approaches to categorizing Protestants. Both methods produce similar estimates of the size of the evangelical population
column296: and they result in similar religious and demographic portraits of the major Protestant traditions.13 (For details on the difference between the denominational and the self-identification approach to subdividing Protestants
column297: see Question 3 above.) To illustrate the overlap between the denominational and self-identification approaches
column298: this analysis is restricted to whites who self-identify as Protestants
column299: since the self-identification approach typically focuses on white born-again or evangelical Protestants and white non-evangelical Protestants
column300: with black Protestants sorted into their own category (see Question 3 above for more details).14 In the 2014 Religious Landscape Study
column301: more than three-quarters of white Protestants (78%) would have been categorized the same way under either the denominational or self-identification approach
column302: including 49% who qualify as evangelicals under both the denominational and self-identification approaches and 29% who are categorized as non-evangelical (or mainline) Protestants under either approach. Just 22% of white Protestants would have been classified differently under the denominational and self-identification approaches. The data show
column304: that the correspondence between the denominational and self-identification approach is
column306: growing closer over time. In the first Religious Landscape Study
column308: a slightly smaller share of white Protestants (76%) would have been categorized the same way under both approaches. Looked at another way
column309: the data show that fully eight-in-ten of those classified as white evangelical Protestants under the denominational approach (82%) answer the self-identification question affirmatively
column310: saying yes when asked whether they would describe themselves as a born-again or evangelical Christian. And nearly three-quarters of those classified as mainline Protestants under the denominational approach (73%) answer the self-identification question by saying no
column311: they do not consider themselves to be born-again or evangelical Christians.15 Similarly
column312: the vast majority of white Protestants who self-identify as born-again or evangelical Christians are classified as evangelicals under the denominational approach (82%)
column313: and roughly seven-in-ten white Protestants who do not self-identify as born-again or evangelical Christians are categorized as mainline Protestants under the denominational approach. The data also show that the two approaches
column314: the denominational approach and the self-identification method
column315: produce identical estimates of the overall size of the white evangelical and non-evangelical (or mainline) Protestant categories. Using the denominational approach
column316: the Landscape Study estimates that 19% of all U.S. adults are white evangelical Protestants and 13% of all U.S. adults are white mainline Protestants. The self-identification approach produces identical estimates; 19% of all U.S. adults are white born-again or evangelical Protestants
column317: and 13% are white non-evangelical Protestants. The demographic profiles of evangelical and non-evangelical Protestants are exceedingly similar under either measurement approach. For example
column318: 54% of white evangelicals are women when the denominational strategy is employed
column319: and 55% of white evangelicals are women when the self-identification approach is used. With respect to educational attainment
column320: the data show that 34% of white mainline Protestants defined using the denominational approach are college graduates
column321: as are 33% of white non-evangelical Protestants under the self-identification approach. Evangelicals as defined using the denominational method are somewhat younger than self-identified evangelicals
column322: and mainline Protestants defined by the denominational method are somewhat older than non-evangelical Protestants categorized as such under the self-identification method. Overall
column324: the two methods for classifying white Protestants produce very similar demographic profiles. Religiously
column325: white evangelical Protestants are much more observant than are white mainline Protestants under both the denominational and self-identification approaches to categorization. For instance
column326: 83% of white evangelical Protestants as defined by the self-identification approach say they pray every day
column327: as do 48% of white mainline Protestants; the gap
column329: between the share of white evangelicals who pray every day and the share of white mainline Protestants who do the same is 35 points under the self-identification approach. When white Protestants are divided into evangelical and mainline categories using their denominational affiliation
column330: the gap in daily prayer is 26 points (79% among evangelicals vs. 53% among mainline Protestants). The data reveal a similar pattern with respect to political opinions. Evangelicals are substantially and consistently more Republican and more conservative than mainline Protestants regardless of the measurement strategy. For example
column331: evangelicals are 18 points more likely than white mainline Protestants to say they identify with or lean toward the Republican Party under the self-identification approach
column332: and they are 17 points more likely than mainline Protestants to say they favor the GOP when the denominational strategy is used. Religion11/08/2018 Fact Tank09/06/2018 Fact Tank03/01/2018 Internet & Tech03/01/2018 Internet & Tech05/31/2018 1615 L St. NW

column335: attitudes and trends shaping the world. It conducts public opinion polling

But the press corps didn’t help itself Wednesday with behavior that sometimes bordered on obnoxious. There are a number of things that the president can say about the midterms. He helped the Republicans increase their margin in the Senate

But a somewhat different reality began to set in early in the evening as the familiar contours of red and blue America powerfully reasserted themselves.” Those who say nothing really changes now for the president are just engaging in spin.
